questions.text: The structure that divides the liver in Couinaud's classification system Is:
questions.solution:
According to Couinaud's classification scheme, the portal vein is the structure that separates the liver.
The most widely used classification scheme for explaining the liver's functional anatomy is the Couinaud classification. The distribution of the hepatic portal venous branches throughout the liver parenchyma serves as its foundation. Each segment has lymphatic and biliary drainage, as well as an independent dual vascular inflow.

The posterior section is the one that corresponds to the gross anatomical caudate lobe.

The remaining parts are arranged as follows:

Sections of the Liver:

Right anterior sections: Parts V and VIII

posterior regions on the right: Segments VI, VII

Part IV of the left medial portion (quadrate lobe)

Lateral parts on the left: Segments II and III

Trochanters, greater and lesser:

Larger Trochanter:

a large, quadrangular structure that joins the femur's shaft and neck.

There is no sensation in the inferior trochanter.

questions.text: Which modification will lead to a change in the biological activity of the hormone given in the picture?
questions.solution:
Insulin is the hormone that is portrayed in the picture. Among the alternatives, depending on the modification, short- and long-acting insulin variants are formed by altering amino acids 29 and 30 in the B-chain.

Organization:

Insulin's basic structural components are two polypeptide chains:

A-chain: twenty-one amino acids

A chain: thirty amino acids

There are two interchain disulfide bonds in insulin:

1. In between the seventh A-chain amino acid and the seventh B-chain amino acid

2. In the space between the A-chain's 20th and B-chain's 19th amino acids

The A-chain also has one intrachain disulfide link, which is situated between the sixth and eleventh amino acids.

Changes:

By altering particular amino acids, several short- and long-acting insulin analogs have been created.

questions.text: Which of the following shows functional assessment of B1 deficiency?
questions.solution:
The most widely used technique for evaluating the functional impact of thiamine deficiency is the erythrocyte (RBC) transketolase test. RBC transketolase activity is reduced in thiamine (Vitamin B1) deficiency, as thiamine diphosphate functions as a coenzyme for transketolase. The activation of apotransketolase upon the addition of thiamine diphosphate to an erythrocyte lysate in vitro signifies a Vitamin B1 deficit.

questions.text: The catalytic efficiency of enzyme is best expressed by which of the following kinetic constants:
questions.solution:
Catalytic efficiency is expressed as the ratio of Kcat to Km. Kcat, or the turnover number, represents the rate constant of an enzyme-catalyzed reaction when the enzyme is saturated with substrate. Km, known as the Michaelis-Menten constant, is the substrate concentration at which the initial reaction velocity (Vo) is half of the maximum velocity (1/2 Vmax). In some enzymes, once the substrate (S) binds to the enzyme (E), forming the enzyme-substrate complex (ES), the product is generated almost instantaneously. In these cases, the rate-limiting step of the reaction E + S ? ES is determined by the diffusion rate of the molecules in solution. Enzymes with this characteristic are termed diffusion-limited or catalytically perfect enzymes. Examples of catalytically perfect enzymes, where the catalytic efficiency (Kcat/Km) reaches the

questions.text: Which of the following does not happen in 5' to 3' direction?
questions.solution:
Before translation, the coding sequence of mRNA is changed through a process known as RNA editing, which happens in the 3' to 5' direction. In order to complete this editing, more uracil (U) nucleotides are inserted at the 3' end of the mRNA and moved from 3' to 5'. In this mechanism, guide RNA (gRNA) acts as a template.

The apoB gene and its mRNA are a well-known example of RNA editing.

questions.text: Child presents with hypotonia and seizures. It was confirmed to be Zellweger syndrome. Which among the following accumulates in brain in this condition?
questions.solution:
The brains of those who have Zellweger syndrome have been found to contain elevated quantities of very long-chain polyenoic acids.

Another name for Zellweger syndrome is cerebro-hepato-renal syndrome; it is an autosomal recessive condition. Hepatomegaly, renal cysts, and compromised neural migration and myelination are its defining features. The disorder is brought on by a decrease in or total lack of functional peroxisomes in different organs, which causes very long-chain polyenoic acids to build up in the brain. Affected people experience significant neurological problems and typically do not survive past their first year of life.

Reference :

questions.text: Assertion (A): Central dogma says DNA is transcribed into RNA which is subsequently translated into proteins. Reason (R): Retrovirus has reverse transcriptase of central dogma where RNA is first converted into DNA which is then transcribed to RNA, which is subsequently translated into proteins.
questions.solution:
Three major channels for the transmission of genetic information are described by the fundamental theories of molecular biology:

1. Replication: The process of creating daughter DNA molecules with the same nucleotide sequences by copying the original DNA.

2. Transcription: The process by which genetic information is converted from a DNA strand to RNA.

3. Translation: On ribosomes, information from mRNA is transformed into a polypeptide chain that eventually folds into a useful protein.

The reason is an expansion of this initial hypothesis, whereas the assertion deals with the core tenet.

Additional processes including reverse transcription and RNA replication, which are seen in some viruses, are included in the extension of the central dogma theory:

Reverse Transcription: The RNA-dependent DNA polymerase enzyme synthesizes DNA from RNA in certain viruses, such as retroviruses.

Reference :
1.Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry 30th Edition - Page no 364
2. Jawetz, Melnick&Adelberg's Medical Microbiology 27th aaa Edition - Page no. 405

questions.text: Type of mutation seen in sickle cell anemia:
questions.solution:
A point mutation in the ?-globin gene, resulting in a single base change (adenine (A) to thymine (T) at the sixth codon of the DNA sequence, causes sickle cell anemia. The mRNA sequence changes from GAG to GUG as a result of this substitution, which modifies the codon from GAG in the normal gene to GTG in the sickle cell gene. As a result, valine rather than glutamic acid is encoded by the mutant gene.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an example of feed forward control mechanism?
questions.solution:
Heart rate increases brought on by exercise are not an example of feedforward control. But even just considering working out and feeling your heart rate go up would be an example of feedforward control.

In feedforward control, an adaptive or anticipatory response is made in the absence of a certain signal.

For example, in temperature control, changes in external temperature do not alter core body temperature until the hypothalamus initiates thermoregulatory responses. Thus, one example of feedforward control is shivering in response to cold.

Similarly, food itself does not trigger stomach secretion during the cephalic phase of the process; rather, the mere notion of eating does.

The cerebellum also uses feedforward inhibition to restrict the amount of time that any given afferent input can excite a neuron.

Reference:
1.Ganong's Review Of Medical physiology, 26th Edition , Page no. 129, 245
2.Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology, 13th Edition , Page no. 9, 10

questions.text: Which hormone crosses the plasma membrane for its action?
questions.solution:
For thyroxine to work, it must get through the plasma membrane. Thyroxine attaches to thyroid hormone receptors inside the nucleus. The hormone-receptor complex then uses zinc fingers to connect with DNA, increasing the expression of several genes involved in controlling cell activity. Despite being a derivative of an amino acid, thyroxine enters the cell through certain transporters, suggesting that it functions by influencing intracellular receptors that are located in the nucleus.

On the other hand, insulin, glucagon, and adrenaline bind to cell surface receptors.

Reference :
1. Ganong's Review Of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition - Page no. 296 and 362
2.Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology, 14th Edition - Page no: 998

questions.text: Pacemaker generating the rhythm for breathing is
questions.solution:
The primary pacemaker responsible for automatic breathing is the Pre-Botzinger complex, which is situated in the medulla. It is made up of neurons that discharge rhythmically, signaling the phrenic motor neurons to begin the inspiration phase. There are two systems that control breathing:

1. Voluntary Control: Operated by the corticospinal tract and the cerebral cortex.

2. Automatic Control: Managed by pacemaker cells located in the medulla's Pre-Botzinger complex. These cells stimulate motor neurons through the thoracic spinal cord (external intercostal muscles) and cervical spinal cord (phrenic nerve, controlling the diaphragm).

The control of expiratory and inspiratory muscles is inversely correlated: motor neurons controlling expiratory muscles are inactive when those controlling inspiratory muscles are active, and vice versa.

Reference :
Ganong's Review Of Medical physiology, 26th Edition - Page no. 646

questions.text: The function of the Golgi tendon organ is to
questions.solution:
Muscle tension variations are sensed by the Golgi tendon organ. The Golgi tendon reflex is disynaptic and acts in opposition to the stretch reflex. It is also referred to as the inverse myotatic or inverse stretch reflex.

An immediate relaxation occurs in a constricted muscle when a considerable increase in tension triggers the Golgi tendon organ's inhibitory reaction. This reaction, referred to as the lengthening reaction, acts as a defense mechanism to stop tendons from avulsing from their bone attachments or muscles from tearing.

Remember that muscle spindles track variations in muscle length, or stretch.

Reference
Ganong's Review Of Medical physiology, 26th Edition - Page mum NO 228 and 229

questions.text: Single breath nitrogen method is used for measuring
questions.solution:
Fowler's approach, or the single-breath nitrogen curve, can be used to assess anatomic dead space.

The portion of the respiratory system that is not involved in gas exchange in the alveoli is referred to as anatomic dead space.

The amount of gas in the alveoli that is not involved in gas exchange with the blood is known as alveolar dead space, and it wastes ventilation.

The combination of anatomical and alveolar dead space is known as physiological or total dead space.

One can compute the total or physiological dead space using the Bohr equation.

Reference
1. Ganong's Review Of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition , Page nos 622
2. Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology, 13th Edition , Page no 526

questions.solution:
Statement 1: GFR = Kf [(PGC — PT) - (?GC - ?T)] is the formula for the Glomerular Filtration Rate (GFR), where:

The product of the effective filtration surface area and the glomerular capillary wall hydraulic conductivity/permeability is the glomerular ultrafiltration coefficient, or Kf.

The oncotic pressure of plasma in the glomerular capillaries is denoted by ?GC.

The tubule's oncotic pressure, or Bowman's space, is represented by the value ?T.

Although mesangial cell contraction does not directly alter the hydrostatic pressure in the Bowman's capsule, it does affect Kf by decreasing the filtration surface area.

questions.text: Afferent fibers from baroreceptors for blood pressure control goes to?
questions.solution:
Blood pressure-regulating afferent fibers project to the Nucleus Trochanteralis (NTS). The baroreceptors are triggered when blood pressure rises, and this triggers a negative feedback response to reduce the blood pressure rise.

Mechanism of baroreceptor reflex:

Blood pressure rises cause baroreceptors to become active, which then triggers the NTS.

The stimulation of the Rostral Ventrolateral Medulla (RVLM) is caused by the NTS, which also activates the Caudal Ventrolateral Medulla (CVLM).

The sympathetic nervous system is thereby inhibited.

Furthermore, the Cardiovagal Center (CVC) is activated by NTS activation, which encourages parasympathetic activity.

Overall:

reduction in blood pressure (BP) and heart rate (HR) due to parasympathetic system stimulation and sympathetic system inhibition.

Shortcuts:

Nucleus Tractus Solitariius, or NTS

Cardiovagal Center, or CVC

Caudal Ventrolateral Medulla, or CVLM

RVLM
Reference :
Ganong's Review Of Medical physiology, 26th Edition – Page no. 577 and 578

questions.text:
Which of the following is true regarding the given statements: 

Assertion: Sacubitril/Valsartan is indicated in the treatment of NYHA class II to IV in heart failure with reduced ejection fraction. 

Reason: Sacubitril/Valsartan is an angiotensin receptor-neprilysin inhibitor (ARNI) counteracts RAAS system and raises the level of vasoactive peptides.
questions.solution:
Angiotensin receptor blocker Valsartan and neprilysin inhibitor Sacubitril together create ARNI (Angiotensin Receptor-Neprilysin Inhibitor). This combination increases levels of endogenous vasoactive peptides, such as natriuretic peptides, bradykinin, and adrenomedullin, which are normally destroyed by neprilysin, while inhibiting the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS).

Patients with chronic heart failure who fall into NYHA classes II to IV and have a left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF) of ?40% are considered to have heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF), and are eligible for ARNI. Hospitalizations for heart failure, overall mortality, and cardiovascular mortality have all been demonstrated to decrease with ARNI when compared to ACE inhibitors alone.

Reference:
Goodman & Gillman's The Pharmacological Basis Of Therapeutics , 13th Edition
Page no. 532, 535

questions.text:
Assertion: Higher doses of acyclovir are advised for the treatment of genital herpes in individuals with HIV.

Reason: Patients with HIV experience more severe or frequent recurrences of genital herpes.
questions.solution:
claim.

° Herpes virus infections can be successfully treated with acyclovir. It works best against HSV-1, then in decreasing order against HSV-2, VZV, EBV, and CMV.

° In the first seven to ten days after onset of genital herpes, 200 mg of acyclovir should be taken five times a day.

* More severe and frequent HSV and VZV infections can happen in immunocompromised persons. Higher doses of oral acyclovir (800 mg five times daily for five to ten days) are needed to treat VZV infections because acyclovir is less effective against VZV.

Reference :
Goodman & Gillman's The Pharmacological Basis Of Therapeutics , 13th Edition , Page no. 1107

questions.text:
SGLT-2 inhibitors are recently used for type 2 diabetes mellitus. Which of the following are the rare but serious side effects? 

a. Ketoacidosis 
b. Fournier gangrene 
c. Urosepsis
d. Angioedema
questions.solution:
Inhibitors of the sodium-glucose transporter-2 (SGLT-2) have recently received approval for the treatment of type 2 diabetes.

SGLT-2 is a protein found in the proximal tubule of the kidney, responsible for reabsorbing glucose. Together with sodium, it transports glucose against its gradient of concentration (cotransport). 80–90% of the reabsorption of glucose happens via these transporters.

These medications lower blood glucose levels and cause glycosuria by blocking SGLT-2, which stops glucose from being reabsorption from the tubular lumen.

SGLT-2 inhibitors that are currently on the market include empagliflozin, dapagliflozin, and canagliflozin.

The following are SGLT-2 inhibitor side effects:

Amputations of lower limbs

Low blood pressure

ketoacidosis in diabetics

acute damage to the kidneys

Pyelonephritis and urosepsis

Hypoglycemia risk is higher when insulin or insulin secretagogues are administered.

Perineal necrotizing fasciitis (Fournier's gangrene)

illnesses caused by genital mycotics

hypersensitivity responses, such as

Reference
Goodman & Gillman's The Pharmacological Basis Of Therapeutics - 13th Edition - Page no 880

questions.text:
Match the preferred antimicrobial drugs to the corresponding organisms:
 
Antimicrobial Drug Organism
1 Praziquantel a lumbricoides
2 Mebendazole b Tape worm
3 Nitazoxanide c Filariasis
4 DEC d Leishmaniasis
e Giardiasis
f Onchocerca volvulus
questions.solution:
The following is the proper pairing of the prescribed medications with the organisms for which they are intended:

Praziquantel: Vermiculite

Mebendazole: Acryloides lumbricoides

Giardiasis and nitazoxanide

Filariasis using DEC (Diethylcarbamazine)

The best medication for treating schistosome infections is praziquantel, which is also effective against the majority of trematode and cestode (tapeworm) infections.

The recommended medication for treating illnesses caused by hookworm, pinworm, trichuriasis, ascariasis, and trichinosis is metronidazole.

Nitazoxanide: Giardia lamblia and Cryptosporidium parvum are two recent infections for which it has been licensed. It is not the first-line treatment for these infections, though. Metronidazole or tinidazole are the preferred medications for treating giardiasis, however paromomycin is better for treating Cryptosporidium species.

The recommended medication for treating filariasis, loiasis, and tropical eosinophilia is diethylcarbamazine (DEC).
Reference
1.Goodman & Gillman's The Pharmacological Basis Of Therapeutics - 13th Edition - Page no 1008

questions.text: Consider the following statements regarding P falciparum. Which are True/ False?
questions.solution:
Because India's Plasmodium falciparum is resistant to chloroquine, statements 1 and 2 are untrue.

Statement 3 is true since quinine works well to treat simple P. falciparum infections when paired with clindamycin or doxycycline.

Statement 4 is also true since malaria is treated using medications based on artemisinin, such as artesunate, artemether, and dihydroartemisinin. Lumefantrine and artemether work well together to combat simple P. falciparum infections.

Statement 5 is accurate as well because medications based on artemisinin are short-acting and are never used as monotherapy; instead, they are always used in conjunction with other medications.
Reference: Katzung Basic and Clinical Pharmacology, 13th edition, pages 890-892..

choices.text: a, b, c and d are correct

questions.text:
Chlorpromazine is an antipsychotic that also acts as an anxiolytic and produces adverse effects like sedation, dry mouth, and hypotension. All of these actions are due to antagonism of which receptors.
a. D1, D2, and 5HT2
b. M1, M2 and A1, A2
c. GABA and beta receptors
d.H1
questions.solution:
Chlorpromazine operates on a number of receptors, which can have a variety of positive and negative impacts on health.

Its antipsychotic effects are due to dopamine receptor antagonism (D2 > D1).

Its antidepressant, anti-aggressive, and anxiolytic effects are partly attributed to 5-HT receptor antagonism.

Blockade of the H1 receptor causes drowsiness and weight gain.

Antimuscarinic effects include dry mouth, impaired vision, constipation, urinary problems, sinus tachycardia, ECG abnormalities, and memory loss. These symptoms are caused by the blocking of M1 and M2 muscarinic acetylcholine receptors.

Antagonism between the alpha1/alpha2 receptors can result in reflex tachycardia and hypotension.
Reference: Goodman & Gilman's The Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 13th Edition, Pages 291-292.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an adverse effect of salbutamol?
questions.solution:
Rather than hypoglycemia, large dosages of salbutamol can result in hyperglycemia.

Option A: Reflex sympathetic stimulation induces tachycardia by acting both directly on cardiac ?1 receptors (because ?2 selectivity diminishes at increasing dosages) and via vasodilating ?2 receptors.

Option B: Receptor desensitization causes tolerance to develop over time.

Option C: The direct impact on skeletal muscle causes an increase in the absorption of potassium ions, which results in hypokalemia.

Reference: Goodman & Gilman's The Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 13th Edition, page 732.

The following drugs are commonly used in the prevention and management of postpartum hemorrhage:

Oxytocin

Ergot derivatives, including methergine and ergonovine

Carboprost, a prostaglandin analogue of PGF2?

Dinoprostone, a naturally occurring prostaglandin E2 (PGE2)

Misoprostol, a synthetic prostaglandin E1 (PGE1) analogue

questions.text: Clostridium difficile associated diarrhea occurs maximally due to:
questions.solution:
The main cause of diarrhea caused by Clostridium difficile is lincosamide usage, including clindamycin. When medications alter the normal gut microbiota, C. difficile infections arise, leading to antibiotic-associated colitis. The most often implicated antibiotics are cephalosporins, clindamycin, fluoroquinolones, and broad-spectrum penicillins.

Hospitals and nursing homes, where there is a high rate of antibiotic use and environmental contamination with C. difficile spores, are common sites of C. difficile infection.

Any antibiotic can cause this illness, but the ones that are most frequently linked to it include:

Clindamycin

Cephalosporins of the third generation, such as cefotaxime, ceftriaxone, cefuroxime, and ceftazidime

Fluoroquinolones, including levofloxacin, moxifloxacin, and ciprofloxacin

Wide-ranging penicillins

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, pg. 1066

questions.text: A 53 year old man is found to have stage 2 hypertension without any co morbidities. Which drug will you start?
questions.solution:
When treating hypertension in persons without comorbidities, chlorthalidone is the first medication that should be used. Other first-choice medications for treating hypertension in these individuals consist of:

Hydrochlorothiazide is generally not preferred over chlorthalidone when it comes to thiazide diuretics.

Calcium channel blockers: Extended-release, long-acting dihydropyridines are preferred.

ACE inhibitors: Enalapril and ramipril (given twice daily) are the alternatives, however captopril is recommended for starting therapy.

Reference :Goodman & Gillman's The Pharmacological Basis Of 13th Edition , Page nos 523, 524, 543 and 544

questions.text:
Which of the following is correct regarding digoxin:
a) Earliest side effect is nausea and vomiting
b) Causes non-specific colour vision
c) Hypokalemia is associated with digoxin toxicity
d) It causes hypomagnesemia
questions.solution:
Choices A and C are accurate:

A: Nausea and vomiting are the first symptoms of digoxin poisoning.

B: Digoxin mostly impairs color vision, causing yellow vision, or xanthopsia.

C: Especially when digitalis is present, hypokalemia raises the likelihood of both early and delayed afterdepolarizations as well as ectopic pacemaker activity.

D: Digitalis poisoning causes hyperkalemia rather than hypomagnesemia. In actuality, the risk of digitalis toxicity is elevated by hypomagnesemia.

Reference:
Goodman & Gilman's The Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 13th Edition, pg. 565.

choices.text: 5), phenobarbitone (7.2), and diazepam (3.3), determine whether the following statements are true or false:
Paracetamol is in a non-ionized form in the stomach and is therefore easily absorbed.
No drugs are absorbed in the large intestine due to its small surface area.
Phenobarbitone is absorbed more in the small intestine than in the stomach.
Drugs that decrease transit time, such as those that cause diarrhea, increase absorption.
Diazepam is absorbed in the small intestine.

questions.text:
<style type="text/css"><!--td {border: 1px solid #cccccc;}br {mso-data-placement:same-cell;}-->
</style>
Given the pH of gastric acid (1-2) and the pH of the intestine (6), as well as the pKa values of certain weak acids and bases like paracetamol (9.5), phenobarbitone (7.2), and diazepam (3.3), determine whether the following statements are true or false:
questions.solution:
The ionization state of a medication affects its absorption. How well a medicine is absorbed depends on whether it is in its ionized or non-ionized state.

Weak acids, like phenobarbital and paracetamol, are easier to absorb since they don't ionize in acidic environments like the stomach. On the other hand, the small intestine has a substantially bigger surface area than the stomach. These weak acids ionize as they pass through the small intestine. The small intestine's enormous surface area maximizes their absorption even if they are in the ionized state there.

Weak bases, like diazepam, are not well absorbed in the stomach due to their ionization in the acidic environment.

Reference Goodman & Gillman's The Pharmacological Basis Of Therapeutics , 13th Edition ,Page no. 14, 16, 945

questions.text: Mw vaccine is extracted from which bacteria, mentioned below:
questions.solution:
The source of the Mw vaccine is Mycobacterium indicuspranii. Chemotherapy and MIP immunotherapy are used to treat category II tuberculosis.

"Pranii" combines the names of Prof. Pran Talwar, who discovered the species, and the National Institute of Immunology (NII), where trials were carried out. The epithet "indicus" refers to India, where M. indicuspranii was isolated.

A 0.1 ml intradermal dosage of the vaccine is divided into two equal halves and injected into each arm. Only one arm receives booster dosages.

Nature Article

questions.text: A hospital has reported an outbreak of MRSA infection. On investigation, it was found out that a staff nurse had nasal carriage of MRSA. Which of the following drugs helps in the removal of colonization of bacteria?
questions.solution:
The recommended treatment for getting rid of MRSA nasal carriers is topical mupirocin.

Mupirocin is licensed for the prevention of MRSA epidemics because it lacks structural similarities with current systemic antibiotics that could cause the development of cross-resistance and has low toxicity when used topically.

It is not recommended to utilize mixed therapy in conjunction with systemic drugs since this could lead to needless antibiotic exposure and the development of drug resistance.

questions.text: Transmission assessment survey is carried out for.
questions.solution:
For filariasis, a Transmission Assessment Survey (TAS) is carried out. In order to stop new infections, the Mass Drug Administration (MDA) seeks to reduce infection rates in the population to a point where mosquitoes are unable to spread the parasites. When infection rates fall below predetermined levels, the TAS assists in indicating when MDA can be stopped. TAS is used as a surveillance tool to make sure that infection levels stay below these target criteria even after MDA has finished.

questions.text: A HIV patient with fever, chronic diarrhea presented to OPD. His stool was examined which showed the following oocysts. Identify the components used for staining the stool.
questions.solution:
Diarrhea frequently indicates a coccidian parasite infection in HIV patients. A modified acid-fast stain is used to identify Cryptosporidium parvum, which is present in images with a blue background and red-stained oocysts.

To stain Cryptosporidium and Isospora species, the modified Ziehl-Neelsen (ZN) method is utilized. The modified Ziehl-Neelsen stain doesn't require heating the chemicals, in contrast to the conventional stain.

The following reagents are used in the modified ZN stain:

Use of pure methanol for fixing

using Carbolfuchsin from Kinyoun as the main stain

Using acid alcohol as a decolorizer

Malachite green or methylene blue as the counterstain

questions.text: Choose the wrong statement about Plasmodium species:
questions.solution:
Because the Duffy antigen normally serves as the parasite's receptor, its absence, as opposed to its presence, provides protection against Plasmodium vivax.

Drug efflux pumps in Plasmodium falciparum are the main source of chloroquine resistance. An ABC transporter that is encoded by the P. falciparum multidrug resistance gene 1 (Pfmdr1) mediates this resistance. Chloroquine resistance has grown over time and is now common in many different areas.

Hemodynamic collapse is an uncommon and severe characteristic of algid malaria, which manifests as shock with severe metabolic disruptions and hypothermia.

Relapses are a common aspect of infections with Plasmodium ovale and Plasmodium vivax. The parasite's dormant forms, known as hypnozoites, are thought to be the cause of these relapses. Infections with P. vivax and P. ovale

Reference
Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine 20th Edition, Page no.810

questions.text: A farmer from the sub-Himalayan region experienced a thorn prick injury a year ago and subsequently developed a warty, verrucous growth at the site of the injury. A skin biopsy was performed and sent for histopathological examination. The examination revealed a characteristic microscopic body in the sample. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A histological picture displaying medlar bodies and a slowly growing warty, verrucous lesion after a thorn prick injury point to chromoblastomycosis.

Often brought on by traumatic inoculation, chromoblastomycosis, also referred to as chromomycosis, is a subcutaneous fungal infection. The original lesion develops into a verrucous, wart-like growth over the course of months or years, which may migrate along the lymphatic system.

Histologically, the lesions are granulomatous, and inside leukocytes or large cells are dark sclerotic masses, sometimes referred to as medlar or copper penny bodies.

Reference
1. Ananthanarayan and paniker's microbiology; 10th edition , Page no: 605
2. Jawetz, Melnick, &Adelberg's Medical Microbiology28th Edition - Page no: 687

questions.text: Which among the following occupation is a risk factor for this presenting illness?
questions.solution:
A parasite infection known as cutaneous larva migrans (CLM) is frequently observed in individuals who work in kennels or other environments where animal excrement is present. Ancylostoma braziliense is one of the animal hookworm species that cause this illness. Usually, these larvae are found beneath houses and on sandy beaches. Thus, unlike swimming in man-made pools, swimming in natural bodies of water is risky.

Usually, the infection begins with an inflammatory papule where the hookworm larvae pierce the skin, usually between the toes. The larvae leave behind serpentine or linear tracks as they move through the lower extremities' and trunk's epidermis.

The suggested course of treatment for CLM is ivermectin. An oral dose of 200 μg/kg is the typical dosage.

Reference: Jawetz, Melnick and adelberg's Medical Microbiology, 28th Edition,Page no.112

questions.text: A patient is diagnosed with Hepatitis B infection. Which of the following markers will always be present in his serum, even during recurrences, or if he develops chronic hepatitis?
questions.solution:
Anti-HBc antibody is present in patients exposed to HBV, even if they have progressed to the chronic or recurrent stages of the infection. While IgG antiHBc is present in chronic conditions, IgM anti-HBc resurfaces during acute recurrences.

Chronic hepatitis B is associated with the HBsAg antigen but not the anti-HBs antibody.

Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology Tenth edition , Page no. 548

Thymocytes and mature T cells have CD3 on them.

Pre-B and mature B cells have CD19, whereas plasma cells do not have it.

After CD19 and mature B cells, CD20 is present on pre-B cells but not on plasma cells.

questions.text:
Which is the most important light microscopic feature of irreversible cell 
injury?
questions.solution:
Under light microscopy, nuclear alterations such as pyknosis, karyorrhexis, and karyolysis are signs of permanent cell damage.

Ultrastructural characteristics seen in electron microscopy include:

mitochondrial large, amorphous, floccular densities

Blebbing of the cell membrane and loss of microvilli

Dissociation of ribosomes from the endoplasmic reticulum

questions.text: A young boy from high altitude came with fever and weakness and had the following reports - Hemoglobin 17 g%, TLC is 21,000 with neutrophils 25, lymphocytes 30, eosinophils 5, myelocytes and metamyelocytes 40 in peripheral smear. Next step in the investigation should be:
questions.solution:
Measurement of erythropoietin (EPO) levels is the next step in the clinical scenario when polycythemia is suspected (with hemoglobin levels >16 g/dL) in order to differentiate between primary and secondary polycythemia.

EPO levels in primary polycythemia are usually reduced or normal.

EPO levels are typically higher in cases of secondary polycythemia.

Philadelphia chromosome testing and JAK2 mutation analysis are often carried out only when absolutely essential.

The evaluation of bone marrow using reticulin staining is used to check for myelofibrosis, which can develop in the advanced stages of the illness. Peripheral smear results in this instance, however, do not point to primary myelofibrosis. Myelofibrosis is frequently linked to dacrocytes and leukoerythroblastic responses.

Reference
1. Robbins Basic Pathology, 10th Edition , Page no 483

questions.text: Which of the following is not an intermediate filament?
questions.solution:
Tubulin does not belong in intermediate filaments; it is a part of microtubules.

There are three primary categories of cytoskeletal proteins: microtubules, intermediate filaments, and microfilaments.

The globular protein actin (G-actin) polymerizes noncovalently into long, entwined filaments known as F-actin, which makes up actin microfilaments. Double-stranded helices are formed by these filaments.

2. Intermediate Filaments: These are fibers that resemble ropes and are mostly found in polymerized form inside of cells. Intermediate filaments do not actively rearrange, in contrast to microtubules and actin filaments. They give cells their tensile strength, which makes it possible for them to tolerate mechanical stress.

3. Microtubules: A dimer made up of the globular proteins alpha- and beta-tubulin is polymerized non-covalently to form microtubules. Microtubules emanate from a microtubule-organizing center (MTOC) in the majority of cells, where their minus ends are

Reference :
Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10e , Page:11

questions.text: A 36-year-old male with skin-coloredumbilicated papules. Microscopy is as shown below. The most likely diagnosis
questions.solution:
Large, homogenous, ellipsoid cytoplasmic inclusions, typical of molluscumcontagiosum, are shown in the accompanying microscopic image in cells from the stratum granulosum and stratum corneum. This poxvirus-caused viral skin illness usually resolves on its own. The brick-shaped poxviruses are the largest pathogenic poxviruses that infect humans, with a diameter of about 300 nm.

The largest inclusion bodies, reaching 30-35 μm, are intracytoplasmic molluscum bodies, also called Henderson-Patterson bodies, which are visible on a Tzanck smear. Usually, the lesions appear as hard, itchy, pink to skin-colored papules that have an umbilicated center from which a substance like curd may be exuded.

Reference :
Robbins &Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 9e - Page no: 1176

questions.text: Which test evaluates the extrinsic pathway?
questions.solution:
Prothrombin time (PT) measures the plasma clotting time in the presence of an ideal tissue extract (thromboplastin) concentration in order to evaluate the extrinsic pathway of coagulation. This gives an indication of the extrinsic clotting system's overall efficiency.

Chronic physical therapy may result from:

Oral anticoagulant administration, such as vitamin K antagonists

illness of the liver, such as obstructive jaundice

Lack of vitamin K

Intravascular coagulation that is dispersed (DIC)

In rare cases, undetected abnormalities or deficits in prothrombin, factors VII, X, or V

The clotting time of plasma following the addition of calcium chloride and phospholipid, but before to the activation of contact factors, is measured by the activated partial thromboplastin time (APTT), which does not account for tissue thromboplastin. This test measures the intrinsic pathway's effectiveness.

Extended APTT may result from:

Throughout the intravascular

Reference:
Dacie and Lewis Practical Haematology 11th Edition, Page nos. 409-411

questions.text:
Match the following:
 
Column 1 Column II
1 Howell jolly bodies A lg inclusions
2 Dohle bodies B Azurophilic granules
3 Flame cells C Nuclear material remnants
4 Auer rod cells D Remnants of ER
questions.solution:
The following are the correct matches:

1. Howell-Jolly bodies - c. Remaining nuclear material

2. Dohle bodies - d. Endoplasmic reticulum (ER) remnants

3. Ig (immunoglobulin) inclusions in flame cells

4. Auer rods - b. Granules that are azorophilic

Justifications:

1. Red blood cells include Howell-Jolly bodies, which are leftover nuclear material (RBCs). Patients with asplenia, or reduced spleen function, are usually the ones who observe them. They manifest as dense, blue, round inclusions.

2. Dohle bodies, which are blue inclusions inside neutrophils, are the representation of the dilated endoplasmic reticulum (ER). These inclusions are linked to the following conditions:

Sepsis

severe inflammatory conditions such as Kawasaki illness

Syndromes of myelodysplastics

3. Flame cells are plasma cells that have an accumulation of immunoglobulins (Ig) that gives their cytoplasm a fiery red color, especially toward the periphery.

4. Auer

Reference
Robbins &Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 9e, Page no. 583, 615, 636

questions.text: A patient who receives recurrent transfusions for thalassemia develops fever and chills during this time. There is no evidence of hemolysis. Which of the following measures can decrease the rate of transfusion reactions?
questions.solution:
Leukoreduced red blood cells (RBCs) can be used to prevent a febrile non-hemolytic transfusion reaction (FNHTR), as shown by the situation given. Leukoreduction is the process of eliminating leukocytes from blood in order to stop the production of cytokines prior to storage.

FNHTR may be caused by the following elements:

sensitivity to antigens on white blood cells (WBCs), usually acquired during pregnancy or from previous blood transfusions.

Donor leukocytes produce cytokines while being stored.

contamination by bacteria.

Remark: Luspatercept is an erythroid maturation agent consisting of a receptor fusion protein that fuses the human IgG1 Fc domain to a modified extracellular domain of the human activin receptor type-2B. It was just given FDA approval to treat transfusion-dependent thalassemia.

Transfusion responses mediated by non-immune factors comprise:

circulatory overload linked to transfusions (TACO)

Low body temperature

abnormalities in electrolytes, such as hyperkalemia

Reference
Wintrobe's Clinical Hematology 13th Edition – Page nos 574 and 575

questions.text: Acute inflammatory response is not seen in:
questions.solution:
During apoptosis, there is no inflammatory reaction. The membrane of the cell is unbroken during this procedure. As a result, there is no inflammation in the surrounding area or cell content leaking.

However, other types of cell death, such as pyroptosis, necroptosis, and necrosis, entail the breakdown of the cell membrane. This results in an acute inflammatory reaction by causing the contents of the cell to leak out of the cell.

Reference
Robbins &Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 9e , Page nos 39, 40, 59, and 60

questions.text: Which of the following is not a hemostatic agent?
questions.solution:
Hemostatic agents do not include boric acid.

In clinical practice, topical hemostatic drugs include:

1. Dressings for hemostatic fields

2. Hemostatic agents used in surgery

Dressings for Hemostatic Fields

These materials, which are granular and gauze-based, help to enhance hemostasis and aid in coagulation. Mineral zeolite, chitosan, and kaolin are typical active components.

Hemostatic Agents for Surgery

Based on how they work, surgical hemostatic agents can be divided into the following types:

Caustic agents: They break down localized tissue, which causes precipitation and coagulation of proteins. By creating a thrombus, this procedure closes up tiny blood vessels. Examples are aluminum chloride, silver nitrate, and Monsel solution (20% ferric nitrate).

Physical agents that are biological: These substances encourage the activation of platelets and offer a three-dimensional matrix for the development of clots. They are often employed in neurosurgery,

Reference
Consultative Hemostasis and Thrombosis, 3rd Edition, Page 538-543

choices.text: Serum amyloid associated protein is seen in Mediterranean fever.
On congo red staining, amyloid shows apple-green birefringence under polarised light.

questions.text: True or False regarding Amyloidosis:
questions.solution:
Amyloid-associated (AA) type amyloid fibrils are derived from serum amyloid A (SAA) protein. Usually, diseases such as familial Mediterranean fever and secondary amyloidosis are associated with these AA fibrils.

The image shown illustrates the characteristic apple-green birefringence of Congo red-stained amyloid deposits when viewed under polarized light.

Lambda (?) light chains or their fragments make up the majority of the amyloid light chain (AL) protein, however kappa (?) chains may sometimes occasionally be implicated. Transthyretin (TTR) accumulates in the heart of older people with senile systemic amyloidosis. Furthermore, the precursor protein for the amyloid fibril component (A?2m), linked to hemodialysis-related amyloidosis, is ?2-microglobulin (?2m).

Reference
Robbins &Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 9e - Page no 257-259

choices.text: 2 g/dL, requiring two blood transfusions. The first transfusion was completed in 2 hours. During the second transfusion, halfway through, the patient developed shortness of breath and hypertension. His vitals showed a blood pressure of 180/120 mmHg and a pulse rate of 110/min. What is the most likely cause?

questions.text: A CKD patient underwent dialysis with an initial hemoglobin level of 5.2 g/dL, requiring two blood transfusions. The first transfusion was completed in 2 hours. During the second transfusion, halfway through, the patient developed shortness of breath and hypertension. His vitals showed a blood pressure of 180/120 mmHg and a pulse rate of 110/min. What is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Transfusion-associated circulatory overload (TACO), a condition brought on by an excessive or rapid transfusion of red blood cells or plasma products, is suggested by the clinical situation that is shown. TACO's salient characteristics include:

Dyspnea, defined as oxygen saturation at ambient air below 90%

Observable bilateral infiltrates on the chest X-ray

systolic high blood pressure

A 1.5-fold increase in brain natriuretic peptide (BNP) levels prior to transfusion

Transfusions should be given gradually, at a rate of 1 to 2 milliliters of blood per kilogram of body weight each hour, in order to prevent TACO. If necessary, diuretics can also be employed.

Reference: Wintrobe's Clinical Hematology, 13th Edition, p. 576.

questions.text: If DNA is damaged in the cell cycle, which gene causes cell cycle arrest?
questions.solution:
When DNA deteriorates during the cell cycle, the

The G1 phase of the cell cycle is stopped by the p53 gene to allow for DNA repair. If the damage to the DNA is too great to be repaired, p53 initiates apoptosis.

When the p53 gene is mutated, damaged DNA cells continue to divide and have the potential to develop into cancerous tumors.

Reference
Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10e , Pages: 51,294

questions.text: An affected male does not have affected children but an affected female always has affected children. Type of inheritance?
questions.solution:
When a mother has mitochondrial inheritance and a father does not, all of their offspring—male and female—will inherit the disorder. All of their offspring won't inherit the illness, though, if the mother is unaffected and the father is afflicted. This pattern results from the special characteristic of mitochondrial inheritance, in which the illness is transmitted via the mother's mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA), which is inherited exclusively.

In contrast to spermatozoa, which have few or no functioning mitochondria, ovums have numerous mitochondria. Because of this, the zygote's mtDNA is exclusively inherited from the egg, meaning that maternal inheritance is the primary mode of transmission.

As a result, a woman who is afflicted will give the illness to all of her children, regardless of gender. But only her daughters will carry on

Reference
Robbins &Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 9e , Page nos 171 and 172

questions.text: A 58-year-old man died 24 hours after the onset of substernal chest pain radiating to the left arm. On autopsy, an atheromatous plaque was seen obstructing the left anterior descending artery. Which type of calcification is most likely to be seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
Dystrophic calcification is associated with atheromatous plaques and can happen even in the presence of normal serum calcium levels.

The buildup of calcium in tissues that are dead or dying is known as dystrophic calcification. Hypercalcemia can make this process worse, even when it occurs when serum calcium levels are normal.

This kind of calcification is seen in many kinds of necrotic sites. Advanced atherosclerotic atheromas and regions of caseous necrosis, like those found in tuberculosis, are two examples.

Reference
Robbins &Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 9e , Page no 65

questions.text: A 20-year-old male patient is diagnosed with acute myeloid leukemia. The peripheral blood smear picture is given in the image. The cell indicated by the arrow is best described as:
questions.solution:
"Faggot cell," as opposed to Auer rods, is the most accurate answer to the cell-related query. The characteristic, needle-like azurophilic granules known as auer rods are frequently observed in a variety of conditions, but they are particularly noticeable in acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL) patients with the t(15;17) translocation.

"Flaming promyelocytes" are cells that have a bright reddish-purple color and appear to be breaking apart. Granules also appear to be releasing into the surrounding cellular matrix. Promyelocytes with tiny granules seem hazy or dark; these are called "dusky promyelocytes."

questions.text: All of the following can be done to remove confounders except:
questions.solution:
Blinding is intended to lessen bias, such as that of subjects, observers, or investigators; it does not remove confounding variables. Something that is unequally distributed between the research and control groups and is connected to both the exposure and the disease under investigation is referred to as a confounding factor.

Take into account, for example, a prospective study investigating the relationship between alcohol use and the development of lung cancer. Alcohol consumption is linked to an increased risk of smoking, which is one consequence of exposure. Lung cancer risk factors that are unrelated to smoking include smoking. Smoking is a confusing issue in this instance. The study's findings can incorrectly suggest that alcohol promotes lung cancer if this element is not taken into consideration.

There are numerous ways to get rid of or regulate for

questions.solution:
Vitamin D has a higher coefficient of variation than diastolic blood pressure.

The following formula yields the coefficient of variation (CV):

CV equals 100(s/x).

Whereas

Coefficient of variation, or CV

S stands for standard deviation.

X equals mean

By replacing the information in the question with the values in the formula above,

Diastolic blood pressure's CV is as follows: CV(DBP)= 100(11/110)

100 divided by ten

= 10%

Vitamin D's CV is as follows: CV(Vitamin D) = 100(3/18) = 100(1/6)

16.67%

As a result, vitamin D's CV is higher than DBP's.

questions.text: A study was conducted to assess the effect of an intervention for certain disease. The p values for two similar studies A and B with 95% confidence limits, was found to be 0.02 and 0.001 respectively using interventions "X" and "Y" with a control group. Based on preliminary analysis, the result may be interpreted as: A) Both studies A and B are significant B) Study A is more significant than study B C) Study B is more precise than study A D) Study A is more precise than study B
questions.solution:
Both A and C are true statements.

At a 95% confidence interval, the p-value for study A with intervention X is 0.02, whereas for study B with intervention Y, it is 0.001. The null hypothesis is rejected since both studies are deemed statistically significant because their p-values are less than the 0.05 significance level.

Study B's results with intervention Y are more precise and statistically significant than study A's results with intervention X, as evidenced by the lower p-value of study B in comparison to study A.

Reference:Parks textbook of preventive and social medicine 25th edition page no 912-915

While not a toxin, arsenic is a poison.

Any material that, when administered in sufficient quantities, has the potential to cause harm to a living creature, either by severely impairing its function or by killing it, is considered a poison.

Substances produced by biological systems, such as plants, animals, fungus, or bacteria, are classified as toxins, a subclass of poisons.

Consequently, it is true that all poisons are toxins, but not all toxins are toxins.

questions.text: What is the first step in the management of an 18-month-old child with both eyes deviated medially:
questions.solution:
The first thing to do when a child has convergent squint (esotropia) is to measure the refractive error and assess visual acuity. Esotropia and hyperopia, also known as hypermetropia, are frequently linked. Children under the age of three are more likely to have the accommodating kind of esotropia.

First-line treatment for esotropia involves refractive error correction, usually using spectacles. Miotic medications, such as echothiophate, can be used to temporarily manage accommodation when a child—especially one under two years old—is unable to wear spectacles or is noncompliant.

Additional therapeutic alternatives could be:

- Refractive correction with miotics or glasses.
- Orthoptic exercises: Applied when glasses are insufficient to rectify a squint, these exercises aid in bettering the alignment of the eyes.
References:
- Parson's Diseases of the Eye, 22nd Edition, Page 377.
- Comprehensive Ophthalmology by A.K. Khurana, 7th Edition, Pages 363, 370.

questions.text: The test given below in the image is used for:
questions.solution:
The Titmusstereotest is a tool for evaluating depth perception, or stereopsis. For youngsters, the exam uses images of a housefly; for adults, it uses circular patterns. The patient, who is wearing polarized glasses for the test, is shown these images from around 16 inches away.

The housefly image will appear to ascend above the surface in three dimensions if the patient has normal depth perception. The patient will reach above the picture plane and try to pinch the housefly's wings in the air when instructed to do so.

On the other hand, the 3D effect won't be visible if the patient has poor depth perception, making the image appear flat like a standard 2D image.

References:
- *Ophthalmology* by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, page 1208
- *Kanski's Clinical Ophthalmology*, 9th edition, pages 7-9
- *Comprehensive Ophthalmology* by AK Khurana, 7th edition, pages 364-365

questions.text: A person is diagnosed to have diabetes on his 45th birthday. When will you recommend a dilated fundus examination for him?
questions.solution:
When a 45-year-old is diagnosed with diabetes mellitus, it is likely that he has type 2 diabetes, and he should be screened for diabetic retinopathy right away.

The most significant risk factor for developing diabetic retinopathy, particularly proliferative diabetic retinopathy, is the length of diabetes.
The following guidelines are suggested for the initial fundus examination in diabetic retinopathy:

• Immediately in cases of Type 2 diabetes, or within three to five years following Type 1 diabetes diagnosis.

Subsequently, the screening for Type 1 and Type 2 diabetes is repeated annually. If proliferative diabetic retinopathy occurs, screening is carried out more regularly, at two-month intervals.


Reference: Comprehensive Ophthalmology by AK Khurana 7th edition, page 289,285

questions.text: Which of the following is not an etiological factor for head and neck malignancies?
questions.solution:
While vitamin A deficiency is associated with a higher risk of esophageal cancer, it is not thought to be a risk factor for head and neck cancers. Cancers that affect the oral cavity, pharynx, larynx, paranasal sinuses, nasal cavity, and salivary glands are categorized as head and neck cancers. The most prevalent kind of cancer of the head and neck, squamous cell carcinoma, is often linked to alcohol and cigarette use. Sarcomas, salivary gland cancer, and thyroid cancer are examples of non-squamous malignancies.

Depending on the location, different risk factors apply to head and neck cancers:

The usage of alcohol, poor dental hygiene, smoking products (such as Bidi, Chutta, Paan, Khaini, and marijuana), and certain dietary components are major risk factors for oral cavity cancer.

Reference:
Schwartz's Principles of Surgery,10th edition ,Page no-578,579
Sabiston Textbook of Surgery,20thedition,Page no-789-790

questions.text: A young boy with a history of frequent nosebleeds and unilateral nasal blockage. CT scan shows HolmanMiller sign. It also shows the presence of a mass in the nasopharynx that extends into and occupies the pterygopalatine fossa. What is the best treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical picture points to nasopharyngeal angiofibroma in stage IIB. The cornerstone of angiofibroma treatment for stage I and stage II tumors is surgery.
In stage III, when the tumor is incurable or has an intracranial expansion, radiotherapy is recommended.
Chemotherapy can be used to treat residual lesions and particularly aggressive tumor recurrence.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presented with hearing loss that developed shortly after her first pregnancy. Her audiometry report Is given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient with postpregnancy hearing loss is described in the clinical scenario. The audiogram reveals Carhart's notch (a drop in bone conduction at 2000 Hz) in addition to conductive deafness. These results strongly point to otosclerosis.

Sensory neural hearing loss (SNHL), as opposed to conductive hearing loss, is brought on by ototoxicity, Meniere's disease, and noise-induced hearing loss.

Bony overgrowth involving the enchondral layer of the bony otic capsule is the etiology of otosclerosis. Tinnitus and bilateral progressive conductive hearing loss are the symptoms that first appear. Stress and hormonal changes, such as those that occur during pregnancy and menopause, might exacerbate this autosomal dominant inheritance condition.

The most prevalent kind of otosclerosis is stapedialotosclerosis. Here, the lesion begins in the region known as fistula ante fenestrae, directly in front of the oval window.

questions.text: Which ts not an obvious advantage of high pressure oxygen through nasal cannula:
questions.solution:
High flow nasal cannula (HFNC): This type of nasal cannula applies pressure and high flow oxygen delivery.

Benefits of a nasal cannula with high flow:

• The patient is comforted by the nasal prongs' softness and flexibility.
• Heating and humidification of secretions: High-flow environments are superior for heating air to a core temperature and humidifying inspired air. Increased water content in the secretions due to humidification makes secretion clearance easier. Additionally, it prevents epithelium damage and airway desiccation while lessening the effort required to breathe.
• minimizes dead space: By removing expired air from the upper airway and allowing a larger percentage of minute ventilation to take part in alveolar gas exchange, the high flow of oxygen provided minimizes dead space by reducing rebreathing.
• Constant

questions.text: Which cell is not present in the layer marked D?
questions.solution:
The stratum basale is the layer designated D. Stratum basale does not include Langerhan's cells. The majority of Langerhan's cells are found in the stratum spinosum.

In stratum basale, keratinocytes, melanocytes, and Merkel discs are all visible:

(Option A) Keratinocytes make up the bulk of the stratum basale and are the predominant cells of the epidermis.

Merkel discs, or type 1 slow-adapting touch receptors, are shown in Option B.

Option C: Neural crest cells give rise to dendritic cells called melanocytes. Through the dendritic processes, the melanosomes that the melanocytes generate go to the nearby keratocytes.

Reference:Illustrated synopsis of Dermatology and sexually transmitted diseases
,Page no 113

questions.text: You have ordered a patch test for an 8-year-old boy with a history of allergic contact dermatitis. After the application of the patch, when should you ask him to return for removal?
questions.solution:
In order to inspect the reaction site, the patch is withdrawn from the test after 48 hours.

Patch testing measures an individual's susceptibility to a particular allergy. Under occlusive dressings or patches, a battery of suspected allergens is placed to the patient's back. For 48 hours, it is acceptable to keep it in touch with the skin.

• 48 hours: Removing the patch for the first reading in order to identify any delayed hypersensitivity reaction.

• Final reading completed for confirmation after 72–96 hours.

Note: 48 hours is the answer because the question relates to when to remove the patch rather than the final diagnosis.

Reference:Rooks textbook of dermatology,Section-4.23

questions.text:
Arrange the following blisters in order from superficial to deep.
A. Pemphigus vulgaris
B. Epidermolysis bullosa dystrophica
C. Linear IgA
D. Bullous pemphigoid
questions.solution:
The sequence of blisters, from superficial to deep, is as follows:
The first three are Pemphigus vulgaris, Bullous pemphigoid, Linear IgA, and Epidermolysis bullosa dystrophica.

Pemphigus vulgaris: * The most prevalent kind of pemphigus; * Suprabasal blister brought on by autoantibodies against Desmoglein 1 and 3.
* Direct immunofluorescence: a pattern of intercellular IgG deposits that resembles a fish net; * Histology: a row of tombstone appearance, as the suprabasalacantholytic blister leaves behind a single layer of intact basal cells.

* Older people (60–80 years old) are typically affected by bullous pemphigoid.
* There will be subdermal blisters that are tense.
* Unlike Pemphigus vulgaris, there is no mucosal involvement.
* Immunofluorescence: Targeting BPAg2>BPAg1, linear IgG deposits are found along the basement membrane (subepidermal).

IgA linear:

* Along the basement membrane zone, there are also linear IgA deposits (subepidermal)

Reference:Rooks textbook of dermatology 9th edition,Page no 3.17,50.10

questions.text: Topical steroids are most effective in:
questions.solution:
The preferred medication for treating eczematous dermatitis is topical steroids.
Alternatives

* Because steroids cause atrophy, they should not be used in patients who have dermal atrophy.

* Steroids are ineffective for herpes infections because they are linked to immunosuppression.

* Regular steroid use is not advised in cases of rosea because it may exacerbate the illness.

questions.text: The following lesion is seen in a 25-year-old man who came to a primary health centre 5 days after he had unprotected sexual intercourse. On palpation the ulcers were painful. Suppurative inguinal lymphadenopathy was present on the right side. The patient has no previous history of drug allergy. Which kit will be used for the management of this particular sexually transmitted disease?
questions.solution:
The symptom cluster of a non-herpetic genital ulcer is best fitted by the onset of painful genital ulcers and unilateral suppurative inguinal lymphadenopathy five days following unprotected sexual intercourse. If there is no penicillin allergy, kit 3 or the white kit is the course of treatment.
The clinical picture displayed above and the results support a chancroid diagnosis.
Chancroid/Soft Chancre:
* Haemophilus dacrya is the causal organism. * It manifests as many painful vaginal ulcers; * It can cause unilateral painful, suppurative inguinal lymphadenopathy; * It takes three to ten days to incubate. Treatment: Tab. Azithromycin 1 gm single dosage + Inj. Benzathine penicillin 2.4 million units
Note: Kit assignment in the syndromic approach to STDs is predicated on the detection of a cluster of symptoms.
Reference: http://naco.gov.in/sites/default Bell /files/Syndromic%20Poster_REDUCEDpdf

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy had pain ul sores in the mouth with a rash over the hands along with fever. Which of these is the causative agent?
questions.solution:
Fever, painful mouth sores, and tiny, tense vescicles with surrounding erythema on a child's palms and soles are indicators that the youngster has hand-foot-mouth disease. The coxsackievirus A16 is the most frequent cause of this in the world.

There is a seven-day incubation period and the spread occurs by droplets or faecal contamination. The emergence of lesions usually occurs after a minor fever. The distinctive lesions have a narrow border of erythema and a grey blister ceiling. They are somewhat oval in shape. Compared to aphthous ulcers, aphthoid oral sores cause less pain.

The only treatment provided is symptomatic. after most cases, the lesions go away after 7 to 10 days.


Reference;Rooks textbook of dermatology 9th edition page no 117.6

questions.text: A patient with fever and joint pain developed pigmentation on the nose after a few days of taking NSAIDs as shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Chikungunya is suspected based on the clinical history of fever and joint pain as well as the picture displaying the hyperpigmented macules on the nose (chik sign).

The nose and cheeks are the most prevalent areas affected by post-chikungunya pigmentation (PCP). It frequently manifests when the fever goes down and might last for three to six months.

PCP might be misdiagnosed if the right history is not obtained since it mimics melasma.

Fixed drug eruptions are another example of a close differential (FDE). One kind of delayed hypersensitive response is FDE. It is identified by distinct hyperpigmented brown plaques that may develop after vesiculobullous lesions. They can burn when they appear on the lips, hands, legs, face, genitalia, and oral mucosa. They often appear 30 minutes to 8 hours after drug exposure and return there when the substance is exposed again.

Reference: Rooks textbook of dermatology 9th edition page no 118.11

questions.text: Under the Mental Health Care Act 2017, a patient has the right to choose his or her caretaker and future course of action in treatment. What is this provision known as?
questions.solution:
An advance directive is a legal document that grants a patient the freedom to select their caregiver and treatment plan going forward in the event of illness or incapacity. It can also be referred to as a medical directive, personal directive, or living will.

questions.text: A patient says that he feels that there is something wrong with him mentally and it is because of the summer season. How much would he score on the insight scale?
questions.solution:
The patient would score 3, as he is aware of being sick but has attributed it to external factors.

Insight is rated on a 5 point scale:

1. Complete denial of illness.
2. Slight awareness of being sick and needing help but denying it at the same time.
3. Awareness of being sick, but is attributed to physical or external factors.
4. Intellectual insight - awareness of being ill, and that the symptoms are due to own particular irrational feelings and thoughts.
5. Emotional insight - the highest level of insight. Intellectual insight with making significant changes in future behavior.

Mania, delusional illnesses, schizophrenia, etc. all exhibit loss of insight.


Reference Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry - 11th Edition Page no 214

questions.solution:
Depersonalization frequently occurs following a potentially fatal incident.

In terms of one's thoughts, feelings, sensations, body, or behaviors, depersonalization is defined by the DSM-V as experiences of unreality, detachment, or being an outside observer (e.g., perceptual modifications, distorted sense of time, unreal or absent self, emotional and/or physical numbing).

Experiences of unreality or separation from the environment are also referred to as derealization.

1. The existence of ongoing or recurring depersonalization, derealization, or both phenomena.
2. In-progress reality testing, throughout the shows.
3. The symptoms hinder social, occupational, or other critical domains of functioning or cause clinically substantial distress.
4. The disruption cannot be attributed to a substance's physiological effects (e.g.,

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of melancholia?
questions.solution:
Sleep onset Not melancholy, but insomnia is a hallmark of anxiety disorders.

One of the earliest words in psychology to characterize the gloomy state of depression is melancholia. It is still used to describe a depressive mood that is typified by:

• Severe anhedonia

• Waking up early in the morning (terminal insomnia)

• Loss of weight

• Deep-seated guilt (usually related to insignificant incidents)

Sometimes melancholy is referred to as "endogenous depression," or depression that develops without the help of outside stressors or triggers in life.

Reference:Kaplan And Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry,11th edition,Page no 360

questions.text: Which of the following best describes paradoxical suicide?
questions.solution:
The term "paradoxical suicide" refers to suicide that takes place when the victim starts to feel better from their sadness.
This is because, although having suicide ideas, a patient in depression is unable to act on them because they lack the energy to do so. However, when the patient starts to recover from depression, they are able to act on their suicidal impulses.

It is referred to be paradoxical because, in contrast to expectations, there is a rise in suicide risk when the patient is recovering from a medical condition.

Reference:Kaplan and Sadock'sConsise textbook of clinical Psychiatry 11thedition,page no 771

questions.text: A patient was prescribed escitalopram. Which of the following adverse effect is the least likely?
questions.solution:
Escitalopram does not cause sialorrhea as a side effect. An example of a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI) is escitalopram. SSRIs are linked to dry mouth as opposed to sialorrhea.

questions.text: All lung carcinomas for diagnosis requires CECT thorax but MRI is useful in which of the following:
questions.solution:
Because pancoast tumors are associated with soft tissue infiltration, which is best visualized with an MRI, MRI is helpful in this case.

Pancoast syndrome, also known as superior sulcus tumor, is caused by a tumor that grows at the lung's apex and involves the C8, T1, and T2 nerve roots locally.

It commonly manifests as discomfort radiating to the arm's ulnar distribution and as the first and second ribs are destroyed. Patients may exhibit symptoms such as hemoptysis, wheezing, stridor, cough, dyspnea, or post-obstructive pneumonitis if the original tumor is centrally or endobronchially located.

Regional spread can result in the following conditions: tracheal obstruction, dysphagia from esophageal compression, hoarseness from recurrent laryngeal paralysis, dyspnea from phrenic nerve palsy, and elevation of the hemidiaphragm.

Reference:Graigners and Allison's Diagnostic Radiology,6thedition,page no 331

questions.text:
Assertion: Multidetector CT is the investigation of choice for the detection of an aortic dissection.
Reason: In the case of a sufficiently skilled person, even TEE is as sensitive and specific as Multidetector CT.
questions.solution:
Aortic dissection can be diagnosed with MDCT because of its excellent accuracy, wide availability, and quick acquisition and reporting durations.

TEE provides good sensitivity (85–90%) for the confirmation of aortic dissection and can be used on unstable patients. Nevertheless, in the "blind areas" of the aortic arch and distal ascending aorta, operator dependency lessens specificity. Furthermore, the abdominal aorta and its visceral branches, which may be implicated in distal or descending aortic dissections, cannot be evaluated by TOE. The most frequent nontraumatic acute aortic emergency is aortic dissection.

An intimal rip that permits blood to enter the medial layer and creates a false lumen between the inner two thirds and outer one third of the media causes aortic dissection. The real lumen is divided.
Reference:Graigners and Allison's Diagnostic Radiology,6thedition,Page no 558

questions.text: The following image of a FAST scan in a trauma patient suggests:
questions.solution:
The patient's perception of FAST after trauma

indicates a positive FAST because the abdominal cavity has a buildup of fluid. This RUQ Sonogram image shows an accumulation of fluid visible in the thin anechoic area between the kidney (on the right) and liver (on the left).

Focused assessment with sonography for trauma is known as FAST. This quick diagnostic test evaluates individuals for possible thoracoabdominal injury. It takes two to four minutes to complete.

Method:

• Supine position of the patient ° 3.5-5.0 MHz convex transducer* The scanned regions are as follows: * Subxiphoid: check for liver damage in the left lobe and pericardial effusion * Suprapubic area: evaluate for splenic and left kidney injuries; * Right upper quadrant: evaluate for right liver injuries, right kidney injury, and Morison pouch;

Reference: Graigners and Allison's Diagnostic Radiology 6th edition page no 378

Pleuritis, with or without a pleural effusion, is the most typical lung symptom of systemic lupus erythematosus.

questions.text: A 68-year-old male admitted to the ICU for acute exacerbation of COPD develops a sudden onset of palpitations. The following ECG changes are seen. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Multifocal atrial tachycardia (MAT) is the diagnosis in the provided clinical situation of a COPD patient in the intensive care unit (ICU) experiencing palpitations and an ECG with narrow QRS complex (<0.12 s) tachycardia with more than three distinct P wave morphologies.

At least three different P wave morphologies, indicated by arrows in the picture, with rates usually between 100 and 150 beats/min are indicative of multifocal atrial tachycardia (MAT).

Patients with acute sickness and chronic lung disease are typically affected. Most of the time, the underlying triggering illness—in this example, COPD—is linked to the clinical symptoms. There are distinct isoelectric intervals between P waves, in contrast to atrial fibrillation.
The cornerstone of treatment is addressing the underlying illness and rectifying any anomalies related to metabolism. There is no electrical cardioversion

Reference:Harrison's principles of internal medicine 21st edition Page no 1901

questions.text: Calculate the anion gap from the following values: Nat = 137 mmol/L, K+ = 4mmol/L ,Cl- = 100 mmol/L, HCO3- = 15 mmol/L
questions.solution:
The difference between observed cations and measured anions is known as the anion gap, and it may be calculated using the formula [Na+] — ((Cl-] + [HCO3-]).

AG is 22 mmol/L when the provided values are substituted. With an average of 10 mmol/L, normal AG ranges from 6 to 12 mmol/L.

To keep plasma electrically neutral, the anions and cations in it must have equal concentrations. As a result, the plasma does not actually have a "anion gap."

But in the clinical laboratory, only specific cations and anions are frequently measured. Na+ is the cation that is often measured, and Cland HCO3- are the anions. The anion gap is computed without taking into account the value of plasma potassium.

The unmeasured anions typically outweigh the unmeasured cations.

The surge in unmeasured anions will cause the anion gap to widen.

Reference:Harrison's principles of internal medicine 21st edition Page no 360-361

questions.text: All of the following characteristics are found in the pleural effusion fluid of a rheumatoid arthritis patient except:
questions.solution:
The pleural effusion fluid of a patient suffering from rheumatoid arthritis (RA) exhibits low glucose levels (<60 mg/dL).

RA satisfies the Light's requirements and results in exudative pleural effusion. Patients with RA have pleural fluid that has high levels of RA factor and LDH. Patients with RA may experience a cholesterol effusion less frequently. It appears milky or opaque and is sterile. Cholesterol crystals and an increased cholesterol level are the causes of the milky look.

Light's standards are applied to differentiate between

Pleural effusions that are transudative and exudative. An exudative pleural effusion meets one or more of the requirements listed below:

• Protein in pleural fluid/serum > 0.5

• Serum LDH / pleural fluid LDH > 0.6

° Pleural fluid LDH greater than two-thirds of the upper limit of serum normal

In patients with Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD), periodic sharp-wave complexes appear as spikes.

Myoclonus, akinetic mutism, cerebellar/visual abnormalities, and quickly progressing dementia are the hallmarks of this spongiform encephalopathy. It is deadly, and most people die from it a year or less after it first manifests.

questions.text: True about the definition of Postural Hypotension:
questions.solution:
A prolonged decrease in systolic blood pressure of =20 mmbg or diastolic blood pressure of 210 mmHg following three minutes of standing is known as orthostatic hypotension, also known as postural hypotension.
It can show up as worry, weakness or exhaustion, lightheadedness or dizziness, trouble focusing or thinking clearly, and blurred vision.
When there is a decrease in blood pressure due to non-neurogenic causes of orthostatic hypotension, like hypovolemia, the heart rate increases by more than 15 beats per minute to compensate. Orthostatic hypotension in neurogenic reasons can be aggravated or triggered by autonomic stresses such as eating, taking a hot bath, or exercising.

Some of the non-neurogenic reasons for orthostatic hypotension are

Heart pump failure, which includes myocardial infarction, myocarditis, and aortic stenosis; Hypovolemia, which includes dehydration, diarrhea, and bleeding
• Metabolic: pheochromocytoma, inadequacy of the adrenal gland
• Pharmacological treatments: diuretics, phenothiazines, tricyclic antidepressants, alpha-blockers; • Venous pooling: sepsis, prolonged standing, or recumbency.
Reference: Harrison's principles of internal medicine 21st edition Page no 155,156

questions.text: Berry aneurysm occurs due to:
questions.solution:
The artery internal elastic lamina usually vanishes at the base of the neck as an aneurysm grows, forming a neck with a dome shape. Smooth muscle cells are replaced by connective tissue as the medium thins. The dome is most frequently the site of rupture. The wall thins here, and the bleeding-allowing tear is often less than 0.5 mm in length.

Aneurysms that are larger than 7 mm in diameter, located at the top of the basilar artery, or at the origin of the posterior communicating artery are more likely to rupture.

Reference: Harrison's principles of internal medicine 20th edition Page no 1785

questions.text: Tigroid white matter on MR imaging Is seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
In MR imaging, tigroid white matter is observed in Pelizaeus-Merzbacher illness.

It is a rare recessive X-linked condition characterized by dysmyelination of the central nervous system.

The central nervous system experiences a failure in oligodendrocyte-mediated axon myelination due to an alteration in the proteolipid protein gene (PLP1).

Characteristics of the Clinic:

Nystagmus, delayed development, psychomotor delay, seizures, stridor, feeding issues, ataxia, and hypotonia leading to spasticity are among the conditions that can occur.

There exists a correlation between the severity of clinical symptoms and the degree of dysmyelination.

The diagnosis can be verified by genetic study. Myelination is absent on MRI, and aberrant amounts of choline and N-acetyl aspartate (NAA) in MR spectroscopy indicate problems in both myelination and axon integrity.

In contrast to other demyelinating leukodystrophies such adrenoleukodystrophy and metachromatic leukodystrophy, where myelin is generated but then degraded, PMD exhibits a failure of

1. It is false to start Tenecteplase if the CT scan is normal.
In fact, starting rtPA requires a standard CT scan. The CT scan is not meant to detect ischemia; rather, its goal is to rule out bleeding.

2. If the CT scan is normal, Tenecteplase is not started before an MRI. False MRIs are not advised in the acute environment because they may result in needless delays in the initiation of thrombolysis. A CT scan is performed to rule out bleeding in patients who have had an acute stroke and come within the treatment window.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about polycythemiavera Is true?
questions.solution:
Polycythemia vera (PV) is characterized by generalized pruritus, which is a result of mast cell activation caused by the JAK 2 mutation.

Alternatives

Option A: Erythrocytosis and the risk of thrombosis are highly correlated, but not the degree of thrombocytosis.

Option C: The likelihood of H. pylori infection is higher in patients with polycythemia vera.

Option D: The primary cause of death in polycythemia vera is thrombosis. In patients who have not received chemotherapy or radiation therapy, the incidence of acute leukemia is minimal.

In PV, a clonal hematopoietic stem cell condition, platelets, granulocytes, and red blood cells build up without a physiological stimulation. The JAK2 mutation is the most prevalent mutation observed in PV.

Manifestations of polycythemia vera include:

• Thrombosis is the predominant presentation and primary cause of
