questions.text: A patient has recurrent optic neuritis of both eyes with extensive transverse myelitis. Visual acuity in the right eye is 6/60 and visual acuity in the left eye 6/18. The patient showed a partial response to steroids. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient's clinical history, which includes widespread transverse myelitis and recurrent optic neuritis in both eyes with a partial response to steroids, suggests neuromyelitisoptica (NMO), sometimes referred to as Devic's illness.

Optic neuritis and myelitis episodes occur often in this severe inflammatory demyelinating illness. Both unilateral and bilateral attacks of optic neuritis are possible, as is severe myelitis involving three or more adjacent spinal segments.

Acute brainstem syndrome, symptomatic narcolepsy, optic neuritis, acute myelitis, area postrema syndrome with episodes of otherwise unexplained hiccups or nausea or vomiting, acute diencephalic clinical syndrome with NMOSD-typical diencephalic MRI lesions, and symptomatic cerebral syndrome with NMOSD-typical brain lesions are among the main clinical characteristics.

Treatment for NMO acute attacks includes

Both assertion and reason are true ,the reason is the correct explaination of the assertion

questions.text:
Which of the following is true regarding the given statements: Assertion: About 10% of patients with sarcoidosis presents with hypercalcemia and or hypercalciuria along with suppressed PTH level.
Reason: Granuloma converts 25-OH Vit D to 1,25OH Vit D due to the increased presence of 1a hydroxylase enzyme.
questions.solution:
The reason is the proper justification for the assertion, and both the assertion and the reason are true. Sarcoidosis individuals who have hypercalcemia or hypercalciuria make up 10% of the total. The PTH level is suppressed by the increased calcium level.

The 1a hydroxylase enzyme was more active due to the granulomas observed in sarcoidosis, which enabled vitamin D to be converted to its active form, 1,25 OH vitamin D.

Reference: Harrison's principles of internal medicine 20th edition Page no 2603

questions.text: All of the following are the core clinical features for the diagnosis of Lewy body dementia except:
questions.solution:
According to DSM5, orthostatic hypotension is not a fundamental clinical characteristic of Lewy body dementia (LBD).

After Alzheimer's disease, dementia with Lewy bodies, or LBD, is the second most common type of progressive dementia. Lewy bodies are protein deposits that form in the brain regions responsible for thought, memory, and movement (motor control).

According to the DSM-5, fluctuating cognition, attention, alertness, recurring visual hallucinations, and Parkinsonian symptoms are core characteristics of LBD. Severe neuroleptic sensitivity and REM sleep behavior disturbance are suggestive symptoms. Other symptoms of LBD include constipation, orthostatic hypotension, and erectile dysfunction.

Ribastigmine and donepezil are used for LBD, and they may enhance cognitive function while lowering delusions and hallucinations. Psychosis may be treated with pimavanserin.
.

Reference: Harrison's principles of internal medicine 21st edition Page no 3385-3386

choices.text: It commonly arises from the central zone.
Most common type of prostrate cancer is squamous cell carcinoma.

questions.text: Mark the following statements True or False regarding prostate cancer
questions.solution:
1. Rather than the central zone, the peripheral zone is where prostate cancer generally starts. Prostate cancers begin in the peripheral zone in around 70% of cases, the central zone in 15-20%, and the transitional zone in 10-15% of cases.

2. The Gleason score is used to histologically grade prostate cancer.

3. It is not squamous cell carcinoma that is the most prevalent type of prostate cancer. Squamous cell carcinomas make for fewer than 1% of prostate cancer cases, whereas adenocarcinomas account for approximately 95% of cases.

4. Hormones play a role in prostate cancer.
.

Reference
Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery – 27th Edition – Page no.1468

The correct order of removing Personal Protective Equipment (PPE):
A. Gown
B. Mask

questions.solution:
The amount of precautions needed, such as standard and contact, droplet or airborne infection isolation measures, will determine the type of personal protective equipment (PPE) that is utilized. PPE should be worn and taken off according to a process that is particular to that type of equipment.

That being said, the CDC has recommended two protocols for PPE removal.

questions.text: The most commonly involved artery in pseudoaneurysm formation:
questions.solution:
The femoral artery is the artery that is most frequently affected by pseudoaneurysm.

A pseudoaneurysm only affects the intimal and medial layers of the artery wall, whereas a real aneurysm affects all three layers. The most prevalent cause of pseudoeurysms is iatrogenic injury to the artery wall, which occurs from repeated arterial punctures for blood collection or catheterization operations. The femoral artery is the most often utilized artery in endovascular procedures, and as such, it is also the artery most frequently implicated in the development of pseudoaneurysms.

Aneurysms typically pulse when palpated, and auscultation may reveal a systolic bruit.

A bidirectional, "to-and-fro" blood flow seen on Doppler ultrasound is referred to as the "yin-yang sign."

Thrombin injection guided by ultrasonography, endovascular stent implantation, and surgical repair are available treatment options.

Reference
Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, 21st Edition , Page No: 1748

questions.text: After parotidectomy patients complains of loss of sensation while shaving. Which nerve is most likely affected?
questions.solution:
The great auricular nerve is frequently damaged during parotid surgery, resulting in lack of sensation when shaving (GAN).

The second and third cervical nerve roots (C2-C3) in the cervical plexus are the source of the great auricular nerve. It innervates the skin above the angle of the jaw, the pre-auricular area, and the lower portion of the pinna. The GAN's main trunk passes through the sternocleidomastoid muscle and enters the parotid gland's anterosuperior region, where it splits into the anterior and posterior GAN branches. During parotid surgery, the anterior branch is especially prone to damage, especially during the early elevation of the skin flap.

Reduced feeling in the earlobe, pre-auricular region, and angle of the ear can result from damage to the GAN.

Reference:
1.SRB Manual of surgery, 5th ed , Page no: 411 2.Gray's anatomy. The anatomical basis of clinical practice, 42nd edition , Page no: 631-633

questions.text: The probable diagnosis based on the below clinical image of the breast is?
questions.solution:
The image displays the pathognomic hallmark of Mondor's disease, a thrombosed subcutaneous cable linked to the breast skin.

The thrombophlebitis of the front chest wall and breast superficial veins is known as Mondor's illness. It can also happen in the penis or arm. The skin across the chest stretches when the arm is raised, revealing a small, shallow groove next to the cord. Restricting arm motions is the treatment for it, and it typically goes away in a few months without problems or deformities.

Reference
1. Sabiston Textbook of Surgery 20th Edition , Page no 1845

2.Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery ,28th Edition , Page no 924,927, 930

questions.text: Device shown in the image is used for which purpose?
questions.solution:
The leukoreduction filter shown in the picture is intended to extract donor white blood cells (WBCs) from blood. This procedure gets rid of WBC microaggregates, which lowers the chance of transfusion-related responses. Leukoreduction ought to take place prior to blood storage, ideally.

Among the main advantages are a lower chance of:

HLA antigen sensitization (a crucial step in preventing platelet refractoriness in transplant patients)

Reactions during fetal non-hemolytic transfusion (FNHTR)

Transmission of the cytomegalovirus (CMV)

It is significant to remember that leukoreduction serves a general purpose other than preventing the spread of CMV, even though CMV particularly targets monocytes and macrophages (types of WBCs). The secondary effect of lowering CMV transmission is an unintentional benefit.

Additional advantages of leukoreduction could be a decreased chance of:

Disease known as transfusion-associated graft versus host (TAGVHD)

Effects of transfusion-related immunomodulation (TRIM)

Variant transmission Jacob Creutzfeldt

Reference:
Jawetz, Melnick, &Adelberg's Medical Microbiology,28th Edition, Page No. 489

questions.text: Which of the following is used for wound infection grading?
questions.solution:
The Southampton wound grading system evaluates the severity of wound site infections with the following grades:

Grade 0: Normal healing

Grade I: Normal healing accompanied by varying degrees of erythema

Grade II: Erythema with additional signs of inflammation in different areas of the wound

Grade III: Clear or serosanguinous discharge from different sites

The Southampton wound grading system uses the following grades to assess the seriousness of wound site infections:

Grade 0: Typical recovery

Grade I: Variable degrees of erythema along with normal healing

Grade II: Erythema combined with further indications of inflammation in several wound locations

Grade III: Unclouded or serosanguinous outflow from several locations

Grade IV: Discharge of pus

During pre-anesthetic examinations, a patient's physical condition and suitability for anesthesia and surgery are evaluated using the American Society of Anesthesiologists (ASA) grading system.

A collection of clinical criteria called Systemic Inflammatory Response Syndrome (SIRS) is used to diagnose and track critically ill patients who have suffered severe burns, serious trauma, or extensive surgery.

The scoring method used is Acute Physiology and Chronic Health Evaluation II (APACHE II).

References:

1. Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 27th Edition - Page 48

2. Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition - Page 2242

3. Schwartz's Principles of Surgery, 11th Edition - Page 1445

questions.text: Achronic alcoholic patient came to the emergency with pain in the epigastrium radiating to the back and recurrent vomiting. On examination, guarding was present in the upper epigastrium. The erect chest X-ray was normal. What is the next step?
questions.solution:
When a patient with a history of continuous alcohol use presents with upper epigastric guarding, repeated vomiting, and abdominal discomfort, acute pancreatitis is a highly probable diagnosis. Serum lipase levels should be checked after a normal erect chest X-ray eliminates out pneumoperitoneum and perforation. While an abdominal X-ray can be followed immediately by a contrast-enhanced computed tomography (CECT) scan, this is not the most definitive diagnostic for identifying acute pancreatitis.

The most prevalent causes of acute pancreatitis are drinking (25%) and gallstones (70%). Severe, abrupt upper abdominal discomfort is the defining sign. Patients frequently exhibit tachypnea, tachycardia, and hypotension as shock symptoms. Furthermore, discoloration at particular locations may be a symptom of bleeding into fascial planes:

1. The Cullen sign

Reference
1. Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery - 28th Edition, Page no 1271
2. Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no. 2387

questions.text: A patient presents with renal calculus of > 4 cm of the staghorn type. What is the best management?
questions.solution:
The best course of treatment for renal calculi with staghorn that are greater than 4 cm is percutaneous nephrolithotomy (PCNL).

Depending on their size, renal stones may require PCNL, ESWL, or extracorporeal shockwave lithotripsy (ESWL) as initial treatment. While ESWL is appropriate for stones between 0.6 and 1.5 cm, PCNL is advised for stones larger than 2 cm and for staghorn calculi. PCNL is suggested in the subsequent situations:

stones bigger than two centimeters

Calculus of Staghorn

Retrograde intrarenal surgery (RIRS) or shockwave lithotripsy (SWL) failure for renal stones

Anatomical characteristics of lower pole renal stones that reduce the effectiveness of ESWL

Reference
1. Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition , Pg 1476-77

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of qSOFA?
questions.solution:
A measure used at the bedside to help identify patients with suspected infections who are more likely to have poor outcomes outside of the intensive care unit (ICU) is the qSOFA score (Quick Sequential Organ Failure Assessment). Three factors are assessed, with one point given to each:

Low blood pressure: 100 mmHg or less at the systolic level

high rate of breathing (more than 22 breaths per minute)

Intimidation (Glasgow Coma Scale score less than 15)

There are three possible total scores: 0 to 3. Patients outside of the ICU have an increased chance of acquiring sepsis if they have a score of two or higher.

Reference:
1. Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 27th Edition, Page no. 21

questions.text: All of the following are features of SIRS except:
questions.solution:
The body's overreaction to damaging stimuli, such as infection, trauma, surgery, acute inflammation, ischemia, or reperfusion, results in Systemic Inflammatory Response Syndrome (SIRS). Whether the injury is internal or external, the goal of this treatment is to identify and eradicate its source.

When at least two of the following conditions are satisfied, SIRS is diagnosed:

Either hyperthermia (heat over 38°C) or hypothermia (heat below 36°C)

PaCO2 < 32 mmHg or tachypnea (respiratory rate >20/min)

>90 beats per minute, or tachycardia

>12 x 10^9/L, <4 x 10^9/L, or >10% band develops (immature neutrophils) are examples of abnormal white blood cell counts.

SIRS with verified infection is the definition of sepsis.

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, page 59.

questions.text: The most common mediastinal tumor is
questions.solution:
A breast tumor is considered locally advanced breast cancer (LABC) if it is more than 5 cm in diameter, not 4 cm.

Three forms of invasive breast cancer are distinguished:

1. Early breast cancer (EBC): Identified by combining T1 to T2, N0 to N1, and M0 in a TNM combination.

2. Locally advanced breast cancer (LABC) - This category includes any T stage with N2–3M0 as well as T4N0M0 and T3N1M0.

3. Advanced Breast Cancer (ABC): This type of cancer is identified by M1 (distant metastases), any T stage, and any N stage.

Conditions included in locally advanced breast cancer (LABC) include as follows:

1. Breast cancers larger than 5 centimeters.

2. Skin-invading tumors or underlying muscle tumors of the chest (T4 in the TNM staging system).

3. Tumors affecting several local lymph nodes, such as the axilla or subclavicular nodes.

4. Breast inflammation
REFERENCES
1.Sabiston Textbook of Surgery 20th Edition,Page no 860
2.Bailey and Love's short practice of Surgery - 28th Edition ,Page. no 930-943

questions.text: The most common mediastinal tumor is
questions.solution:
In decreasing order of incidence, thymoma (25%) is the most frequent mediastinal tumor, followed by germ cell tumor (13%) lymphoma, mesenchymal, and thyroid.

Thymoma is staged using TNM staging and the Masaoka classification.

Neurogenic tumors are the most prevalent type of mediastinal tumor in children.

questions.text: Mark the following statements true or false about the thyroglossal cyst.
questions.solution:
A congenital midline neck swelling that usually manifests in childhood is called a thyroglossal cyst. It has pseudostratified columnar and squamous epithelium lining it, and heterotopic thyroid tissue is present in about 20% of these cysts. Important characteristics that set apart a thyroglossal cyst from other midline neck swellings are as follows:

It is not movable vertically, only laterally.

It moves as the tongue protrudes and during deglutition, the act of swallowing.

The thyroglossal duct normally closes by the fifth week of pregnancy and is completely destroyed by the eighth week of pregnancy. Although a cyst can develop anywhere along the thyroglossal duct's course, the infrahyoid area is where they most frequently occur. Other potential sites consist of:

Afrahyoid (most prevalent)

area of the thyroid cartilage

region suprahyoid

bottom of the oral cavity

Reference:1. Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, 20th Edition, Page 1861
2.Schwartz's Principles of Surgery, 10th Edition, Pages 1521–1522

questions.text: On the 5th postoperative day post CABG, the patient develops tachypnea and hypotension. What is the most probable cause?
questions.solution:
Clinical indications of tachypnea and hypotension in a post-operative day 5 coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG) patient may indicate lung collapse (atelectasis), which is categorized as type 3 respiratory failure.

The most common respiratory complication in patients recovering from surgery, especially after thoracic, upper abdominal, or general anesthesia, isatelectasis. Symptoms including tachypnea and low oxygen saturation are common. Upon inspection, the breath sounds are usually low-pitched and bronchial.

Within 24 to 48 hours, incentive spirometry, deep breathing exercises (holding five breaths for five seconds each), early mobilization, and chest physiotherapy can all effectively reverse atelectasis.

Additional systemic problems following surgery consist of:

1. Myocardial infarction and pneumonia: These conditions frequently manifest in the initial days
Reference:
1.Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page No: 2221, 2250
2. Sabiston Textbook of Surgery 21st Edition, Page No: 247

questions.text: Pick from the following the usual cause of thyroid storm in thyroidectomy.
questions.solution:
Inadequate patient preparation before to thyroidectomy is typically the cause of thyroid storm. Pre-operative patient preparation includes making sure the patient is euthyroid.

Thyroid storms are not brought on by rough treatment of the thyroid during thyroidectomy. The acinar cells contain a considerable amount of thyroglobulin, but until it is converted to thyroxine, it is dormant (T3 and T4).

Reference

1. Schwartz's Principles of Surgery - 11th edition - Page no 1638

3.Bailey and Love's short practice of Surgery - 28th Edition - Page no 866

questions.text: The best way to manage the wound shown in the image is:
questions.solution:
An abrasion, or superficial skin injury, is shown in the picture. After an abrasion occurs, the wound needs to be cleaned and dressed appropriately.

In order to lower the risk of infection, wound cleansing is crucial for getting rid of bacteria and debris. It adheres to the acronym "TIME":

T - Tissue: Use debridement to identify and remove non-viable tissue or foreign objects.

I-Inflammation/Infection: Identify the underlying cause and assess each wound for indicators of infection or inflammation.

M - Moisture Balance: Make sure that the moisture balance is correct and assess the reason for wound exudate.

E - Edge: Look for any anomalies in the skin surrounding the wound and its edges.

Cleaning the wound with regular saline is known as wound irrigation or wound toilet.

Using a surgical blade or tiny scissors, debridement is done to remove any implanted foreign objects or dead tissue..

Reference

1.Tintinalli's Emergency Medicine: A Comprehensive Study Guide, 9th Edition,Page no 271

2.SRB Manual of surgery, 6th edition , Page no. 8-10

questions.text: In a child with a unilateral undescended testis, a diagnostic laparoscopy is performed which showed the blind-ending testicular vessels on the right side. What is the next best step?
questions.solution:
When a testis is not palpable, a vanishing testis can be diagnosed with laparoscopic identification of a blind-ending vas deferens and testicular arteries before they reach the internal ring. This eliminates the need for additional exploration.

The inability of the testes to pass through the abdomen and into the scrotal sac is known as cryptorchidism. It is the most prevalent genitourinary tract congenital anomaly. The inguinal area is the most common location for testicular descent arrest, which can occur at any time. There are two stages to the descent:

Transabdominal phase: Mullerian-inhibiting drugs control the testes' descent to the lower abdomen or pelvis.

Inguinoscrotal phase: A calcitonin gene-related peptide generated by androgen from the genitofemoral nerve guides the testes as they pass through the inguinal canal and into the scrotum.

While the precise reason for

questions.text: A patient was brought to the emergency department following a road traffic accident (RTA) with chest trauma. He is conscious but can only speak in single words. His respiratory rate is 44 breaths per minute, and his blood pressure is 90/40 mmHg. Upon percussion of the right side of his chest, hyper-resonance is noted. What should be your immediate next step?
questions.solution:
Pneumothorax is indicated by the clinical scenario presented, which involves chest trauma and a hyper-resonant note on the right side. Due to the patient's hemodynamic instability, tension pneumothorax is suspected. This condition needs to be treated right away by decompressing the patient by using the right needle location.

The buildup of air in the pleural space is known as pneumothorax. Among the reasons for air entrapment are:

1. Primary spontaneous pneumothorax: This condition is brought on by the spontaneous rupture of tiny cystic spaces, or apical pleural blebs, that are situated just under the visceral pleura.

2. Secondary pneumothorax - Occurs in lung disorders such as chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) as a result of the rupture of dilated cystic spaces.

The third condition is tension pneumothorax, which is brought on by a one-way valve mechanism that lets air into the pleural space and raises the pressure above atmospheric levels. This extreme pressure stops

questions.text: The most common neuroendocrine tumor of the pancreas is
questions.solution:
With a frequency of 4 per million, insulinoma is the most frequent neuroendocrine tumor of the pancreas. Over 90% of cases of this insulin-secreting tumor are benign. Insulinoma generally manifests beyond the age of 40 in persons without MEN 1 syndrome, however it manifests before that age in those with MEN 1. Hypoglycemia symptoms, such as weakness, headaches, sweating, dizziness, seizures, and abnormal behavior, especially after fasting or physical activity, are the condition's initial signs. When glucose is consumed, these symptoms get better.

A 72-hour fasting test that measures serum insulin and glucose levels is the preferred diagnostic procedure for insulinomas. Affected people also have higher levels of proinsulin and C-peptide.

Options for medical management consist of:

Regular meals high in carbohydrates to

questions.text:
Match the following fractures:
Column 1 Column II
1 Pilon's fracture A Fracture of the styloid process of the radius
2 Runner's fracture B Trimalleolar ankle fracture
3 Chauffer's fracture C Bimalleolar ankle fracture
4 Cotton's fracture D Stress fracture of the distal fibula
E Comminuted intra articular fracture of the distal end of tibia
F Depressed Comminuted Fracture of the lateral tibial condyle
questions.solution:
The appropriate pairing is

1. Comminutedintraarticular fracture of the tibia's distal end, known as a pilon fracture.

2. Distal fibula stress fracture, often known as "runner's fracture"

3. Chauffer's Fracture: Breaking of the radius's styloid process

4. The trimalleolar ankle fracture known as Cotton's fracture

Pott's Fracture is the name for a bimalleolar ankle fracture.

Bumper fracture: depressed comminuted fracture of the lateral tibial condyle.

Reference
Textbook of Orthopedics - Page no. 258, 861

questions.text: At what age in women is a DEXA scan done routinely?
questions.solution:
Women over 65 should have a dual-energy x-ray absorptiometry (DEXA) scan performed on a regular basis to check for osteoporosis.

The most prevalent metabolic bone disease, osteoporosis is typified by abnormally low bone mass, which renders the bone abnormally brittle and raises the risk of fractures.

The National Osteoporosis Foundation lists the following requirements for osteoporosis screening:

* Women 65 years of age or older

* Men who are at least 70 years old

* Postmenopausal women with risk factors < 65 years of age

* Fracture sustained after turning fifty

* Men with risk factors aged 50-69

The aforementioned patients undergo a DEXA scan to measure their bone mineral density; the results are expressed as a T-score or Z-score.

Reference
Textbook of Orthopedics - Page no. 647

questions.text:
True or false statements regarding anterior shoulder dislocation are:
A. Recurrence rate is maximum if the patients age is less than 20 years
B. Axillary nerve is most commonly injured
C. CT scan is preferred for knowing the bony lesion
D. Anterior shoulder dislocation is most Common type
questions.solution:
The gold standard method for identifying bone diseases and determining the degree of bone loss is a three-dimensional computed tomography (CT) scan.

Anterior dislocations occur significantly more frequently than posterior ones, with shoulder dislocations being more prevalent in adults and rather infrequent in youngsters. The anterior glenoid rim gets rounded in anterior shoulder dislocation as a result of the humeral head repeatedly dislocating over it. Patients frequently arrive at the ER with their shoulder abducted, supporting their elbow with the other hand, and sometimes they have a history of similar dislocations.

Axillary nerve damage is the most frequent acute consequence of anterior shoulder dislocation, and it can cause numbness in a limited area on the lateral aspect as well as paralysis of the deltoid muscle.

Reference
Textbook of Orthopedics - Page no. 129

questions.text: The treatment for the condition given below is:
questions.solution:
A giant cell tumor (GCT) is suspected based on the expansive, eccentric, subarticular, lytic lesion in the distal femur's epiphysis that appears like a soap bubble on the radiograph of the knee joint. Extended curettage and autografting are the suggested courses of treatment.

Osteoclastomas, another name for giant cell tumors, usually affect young individuals between the ages of 20 and 40. The proximal tibia is where they most frequently originate, then the distal femur.

Important X-ray features of a GCT consist of:

A single epiphysis-based lytic lesion that may be loculated.

a peculiar location, frequently subchondral.

expansion of the cortical layer above.

a soap bubble appearance, with the tumor appearing loculated and uniformly lytic with trabecular remains.

There is no calcium accumulation inside the tumor.

minimal to nonexistent reactive sclerosis

Reference

1. Essential Orthopaedics by Maheswari, 5th edition - Page no. 237

2. Apley's System Of Orthopaedics And Fractures - 10th Edition, Page no. 198

questions.text: Identify the instrument given below.
questions.solution:
The tool that is offered is a bone nibbler, which is used to carefully nibble or bite away at the tissue in order to remove or shape small portions of bone. It is available in different nose angles and sizes:

Simple nibbler that works well for most applications.

curved nibbler designed especially for spinal operations.

Double-action nibbler: straight and curved versions are offered. The double-action mechanism provides better mechanical efficiency while lowering the force required to cut the bone.

questions.text: Mark True or False regarding Septic arthritis:
questions.solution:
ANS: It is recommended that Incision and Drainage (I&D) occur immediately following the aspirate culture and a 24-hour course of antibiotic therapy. As an orthopedic emergency, septic arthritis must be treated quickly to avoid articular cartilage degradation and related consequences.

For the following reasons, septic arthritis is regarded as an orthopedic emergency:

Depletion of Articular Cartilage Ground Substance: This starts about two days post-infection and is caused by T lymphocyte stimulation during the delayed immune response, bacterial toxins and enzymes, and acute inflammatory response-induced enzyme activation.

Cartilage Destruction: Because of the ground substance's deterioration, this can be seen 4–6 days after infection.

Total Cartilage Destruction: Takes place in around 4 weeks, and may result in problems such osteomyelitis, subluxation, or joint dislocation.

choices.text: Easily managed with gallows traction in elderly.
Interlocked Intramedullary nailing is gold standard for management.

questions.text: Mark True or False regarding Fractures shaft of femur.
questions.solution:
1. More common in older people - False high-velocity injuries that result in fractures to the femoral shaft are more common in younger people.

2. Easily treated in older people using gallows traction - Untrue

Gallows traction is not usually utilized on old patients; rather, it is employed on youngsters under the age of two. By suspending the child's legs from an overhead beam and raising the hips slightly off the bed, the body's weight acts as counter-traction, reducing fractures until sufficient callus formation takes place.

3. Linked to problems with the lungs - This is accurate

Femoral shaft fractures are known to carry a risk of pulmonary consequences, including fat embolism and Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS).

4. The gold standard for management is interlocking intramedullary nailing - True

The recommended course of treatment is closed intramedullary nailing with interlocking screws.

Reference
Textbook of Orthopedics - Page no. 214, 216, 218, and 220

questions.text: Most specific feature for ankylosing spondylitis:
questions.solution:
The most specific sign of ankylosing spondylitis (AS) is bilateral sacroiliitis. HLA-B27 testing is positive in up to 90% of AS patients; however, the condition is not exclusively associated with this marker. Furthermore, even though they are frequently raised, erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) and C-reactive protein (CRP) are not always indicative of AS. AS is not characterized by lumbar laxity.

According to the Assessment of Spondyloarthritis International Society (ASAS) categorization criteria, a patient must have had lower back pain for more than three months prior to the age of 45, in addition to one of the following symptoms:

MRI or x-ray confirmation of saprioliitis, together with a minimum of one standard clinical or laboratory result.

an HLA-B27 test result that is positive and at least two common clinical or laboratory symptoms.

questions.text: Following a fall in the bathroom, an elderly lady is diagnosed with a fractured neck of the femur. Which of the following coexisting conditions is most likely to have predisposed to this injury?
questions.solution:
Osteoporosis is most likely the underlying cause of a pathological fracture in the instance of an elderly woman who sustains a fracture following a small fall. The most prevalent metabolic bone disease, osteoporosis is defined by a marked decrease in bone mass, increasing the risk of fractures and making bones more brittle.

A DEXA scan is frequently used in the following groups to measure bone mineral density and screen for osteoporosis; the results are presented as T-scores or Z-scores:

women who are 65 years of age or older

Men who are 70 years of age or older

Under 65-year-old postmenopausal women with risk factors

Those who fracture after the age of fifty

Men with risk factors aged 50-69

questions.text: A one and a half-year-old baby comes to OPD with a generalized convulsive episode which lasts for 45 min. On duty Senior Resident asked junior resident to start an IV line and left?
questions.solution:
The infant had convulsions that lasted for 45 minutes (more than five minutes), which is indicative of status epilepticus. This is a medical emergency that requires prompt attention.

Diazepam, lorazepam, or midazolam are typically administered intravenously as the first line of therapy. In the event that the condition does not improve, phenobarbital, valproate, and levetiracetam are used as the next line of treatment.

In the first scenario, if the IV line is not accessible, take rectal diazepam, intranasal lorazepam, or buccal or intranasal midazolam.

In case 2: The patient received a diazepam IV treatment initially, but there has been no improvement. Hence, giving an IV phenytoin loading dosage is the next step.

questions.text: Sign of effective neonatal resuscitation is:
questions.solution:
When newborn resuscitation is successful, the strongest indicator is a rise in heart rate. The heart rate is used to gauge how well a newborn is responding to resuscitation at different stages.

A baby's tone, cry, breathing efforts, and respiratory efforts are evaluated as soon as they are delivered. The following actions are taken right away if the baby's breathing is not occurring or if the tone is not good: warming the infant to keep their body temperature at a normal level, opening their airway by placing their head in the sniffing position with their head slightly extended, removing their secretions from their airways, and providing tactile stimulation.

The baby's heart rate needs to be monitored following the first stages of neonatal resuscitation. Should the heart rate be less than 100 beats per minute

(bpm), SPO and positive pressure breathing are offered.,

Reference
Nelson textbook of pediatrics 21st edition, Page no: 927

questions.text: A 3-week neonate presents with ambiguous genitalia with Na+ - 127; K+-6 meq/L with a BP of 50/22 mm Hg. Along with IV fluids, what specific management is done?
questions.solution:
Congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH) is the likely diagnosis in the given clinical case of a neonate presenting with ambiguous genitalia, hyponatremia, hyperkalemia, and hypotension. For this infant's care, intravenous fluids and hydrocortisone must be given.

21-hydroxylase insufficiency is the most prevalent enzyme deficit in CAH. Around 1014 days of age, babies with 21hydroxylase deficiency usually exhibit the subset of symptoms associated with androgen excess, cortisol deficit, and aldosterone deficiency.

Salt-wasting crises characterized by hyponatremia, hyperkalemia, hypotension, and metabolic acidosis are caused by low levels of aldosterone.

Symptoms of a cortisol deficit include weakness, anorexia, vomiting, shock, weight loss, hyperpigmentation, and hypoglycemia.

In cases of androgen excess in 21-hydroxylase insufficiency, females become virilized, resulting in female pseudohermaphroditism, while men experience premature puberty. Virilization is typically noticeable at

For children ages 5 to 12, Group A B-hemolytic streptococcal infections are the main cause of PSGN. Immune complexes including certain antibodies and streptococcal antigens (the M protein of the cell wall) are the cause. Acute nephritic syndrome (PSGN) usually appears 1–2 weeks after streptococcal pharyngitis or 3–6 weeks after streptococcal pyoderma. When there are no additional symptoms that point to a central nervous system infection, febrile seizures are identified.

It is uncommon to see pseudotumorcerebri in children younger than ten. Obesity, feminine gender, pregnancy, and medications including tetracycline, vitamin A, and derivatives of retinoid are associated with this. The majority of cases have papilledema, and the sickness has a chronic course.

Seizures, localized neurological impairments, changed tone, and altered awareness are all signs of intracranial bleeding.

Neisseria meningitidis, Streptococcus pneumoniae, or Haemophilus influenzae type B can all result in bacterial meningitis.

questions.text:
Assertion: The primary treatment for neonatal diarrhea is antibiotics.
Reason: Most cases of neonatal diarrhea are caused by viruses.
questions.solution:
Both the rationale and the assertion stand alone as true statements. The assertion is false.

Rotavirus is the most frequent cause of diarrhea in newborns. Additional viruses that can induce diarrhea are enterovirus, adenovirus, calicivirus, and astrovirus.

Replacing lost fluids and rehydrating with ORS are the cornerstones of treatment.

questions.text:
Sequential arrangement of fetal scans Done in Pregnancy:
A. Triple markers
B. Nuchal Translucency Scan
C. Growth scan
D. Anomalous scan
questions.solution:
The appropriate scan order is

1. Scan for Nuchal Translucency
2. Triangular markers
3. Strange scan
4. Growth analysis

As part of the first-trimester aneuploidy screening, nuchal translucency examination is performed between 11 and 14 weeks. At 11 weeks, its sensitivity reaches its peak.

It is the maximal thickness of the translucent subcutaneous layer that covers the fetal spine at the back of the neck and lies between the skin and soft tissue. If the crown-rump length (CRL) is between 38 and 84 mm, it is measured in the sagittal plane.

The likelihood of fetal aneuploidy and other anatomical abnormalities, such as heart malformations, is markedly raised when nuchal translucency increases.
.

questions.text:
Assertion: Menopause Is associated with hot flashes.
Reason: Hot flashes are because of low estrogen or its fluctuation.
questions.solution:
Hot flushes are defined as waves of 2–5 minutes of facial and neck vasodilation that are followed by profuse perspiration.
Hot flashes can happen more than once in a day, although they usually get worse at night and interfere with sleep. Hot flushes are sometimes accompanied by headache, palpitations, anginal pains, impatience, and lack of focus.
Noradrenaline is the cause of hot flushes. When hypothalamic endorphins are reduced due to low estrogen levels, more norepinephrine and serotonin are released. The disruption of the thermoregulatory system by noradrenaline results in an unsuitable mechanism for heat loss.

Additional reasons for heat flashes include:

* autoimmune diseases; * mast cell disorders; * thyroid illness; * epilepsy; * pheochromocytoma; * carcinoid syndromes; * insulinoma; * pancreatic tumors; * leukemias

Keep in mind that compared to natural menopause, surgical menopause causes more severe vasomotor symptoms.
.

Reference:Shaws textbook of gynaecology 16th edition Page no 74

questions.text: A 33 Weeks multigravida woman presents with epigastric pain, headache, visual symptoms, and proteinuria - 3+. The next step of management would be?
questions.solution:
The clinical case presented, involving a pregnant lady 33 weeks along with headache, ocular complaints, proteinuria 3+, and epigastric pain, suggests severe preeclampsia. IV MgSO4 injection would be the next step in management to stop seizures.

Severe preeclampsia is defined as any of the following conditions:

Thrombocytopenia (<1,00,000 cells per mm3), headache, visual disturbance, upper abdomen pain, elevated creatinine, oliguria, pulmonary edema, significant rise in serum transaminases, and fetal development limitation are some of the symptoms that may be present.

For fetal lung maturity, dexamethasone (option B) is also administered in cases of severe preeclampsia <34 weeks.

However, the best course of action for preventing seizures would be to administer MgSO4 before corticosteroids.

Since there are no contraindications for the patient, an immediate birth is not recommended in this instance.
Reference:Williams Obstetrics 26th edition page no 690,715-717,721

questions.text: Hormone replacement therapy Is not indicated for.
questions.solution:
Hormone replacement treatment is not recommended for the prevention of coronary artery disease. The evidence for starting or continuing estrogen therapy (ET) or estrogen-progestin therapy (EPT) to prevent primary or secondary coronary heart disease (CHD) is currently insufficient.

Hormone therapy (HT) and placebo groups had nearly identical rates of cardiovascular, cancer, and all-cause mortality, according to an 18-year reevaluation of WHI (women health initiative) participants. Hormone therapy (HT) is now limited to treating genitourinary symptoms and uncomfortable vasomotor symptoms (VMS), preventing osteoporosis, and treating hypoestrogenism brought on by surgical menopause, hypogonadism, or premature ovarian insufficiency.

Women who have the following conditions shouldn't use estrogen:

* Abnormal vaginal bleeding that goes undetected

* acknowledged,

questions.text: The correct statement regarding the physiological changes in the respiratory system in pregnancy?
questions.solution:
During pregnancy, the functional residual capacity (FRC) drops by 20 to 30 percent (400 to 700 mL).

Residual Volume (RV) + Expiratory Reserve Volume (ERV) equals FRC. ERV drops by fifteen to twenty percent (200–300 mL). RV drops by twenty to twenty-five percent (200 to 400 mL).

Because of the diaphragm's elevation, FRC and RV diminish. By the sixth month, there are notable decreases that continue to get worse throughout the pregnancy.

Pregnancy-related increases in minute ventilation are caused by a number of reasons. These include compensatory respiratory alkalosis, decreased expiratory reserve capacity, and the stimulatory effect of progesterone. During pregnancy, total lung capacity (FRC + IC) drops.

Reference:Williams Obstetrics 26th edition page no 65-67

questions.text: In preterm labor, which drug has a neuroprotective role?
questions.solution:
Magnesium sulfate, or MgSO4, is thought to have a neuroprotective function in premature labor. Research has indicated that there is a substantial reduction in the risk of cerebral palsy when magnesium exposure is compared to no exposure.

When compared to corticosteroids alone, the combination of magnesium sulfate with corticosteroids has been linked to decreased incidence of neurodevelopmental impairment and death.

Among the suggested channels of action are:

* decreased glutamate presynaptic release

* Glutamatergic NMDA receptor blockage

* adenosine activity is amplified

* enhanced mitochondrial buffering of calcium

* blocking voltage-gated channels that allow calcium to enter

MgS04 is administered as a prophylactic in cases of severe preeclampsia and as an anticonvulsant in the management of eclampsia. In eclampsia, 4–7 mEq/L of magnesium is the therapeutic range. Serum magnesium levels should be measured to keep an eye on magnesium toxicity (if serum creatinine

questions.text: On finding a congenital heart block in a fetus, which of the following conditions would you evaluate for in the mother?
questions.solution:
When a fetus has a congenital heart block, it's critical to assess the mother for systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). Myocarditis and fibrosis in the region between the atrioventricular (AV) node and the bundle of His are frequently the cause of fetal and newborn heart blockages. The majority of these heart blocks affect fetuses whose mothers have antibodies against the SS-A (Ro) or SS-B (La) antigens. Women with SLE can test positive for these antibodies up to 50% of the time. Fetal cardiac monitoring is therefore advised between weeks 18 and 26 of gestation in pregnancies when these antibodies are present.

Most cases of congenital heart block necessitate pacemaker implantation, and the condition is usually permanent. On the other hand, hydroxychloroquine therapy for mothers has been demonstrated to lower the

Reference:Williams Obstetrics 26th edition page no 1113

questions.text: All of the followings are seen in GDM except:
questions.solution:
Gestational diabetes mellitus is not linked to malformations (GDM). Organogenesis is disrupted, resulting in malformations that typically appear in the first trimester. In GDM, the aberrant glycemic state only becomes apparent during the second trimester.

In comparison to the general population, overt diabetes (pregestational diabetes) is linked to increased risks of deformities. prevalent conditions include transposition of great vessels (TGA), ventricular septal defect (VSD), atrial septal defect (ASD), hypoplastic left heart, aortic stenosis, and coarctation of the aorta. Neural tube defects (encephalocele, meningomyelocele, anencephaly) are also prevalent.

Although rare, caudal regression syndrome is a particular abnormality that occurs in babies born to diabetes moms. A rare abnormality that appears in the second and third trimesters of pregnancy is called small left colon syndrome. Alternatives

Option B: Elevated blood glucose in the GDM

questions.text: The risk of fetal varicella syndrome is maximum when the mother is infected between__.
questions.solution:
When a woman contracts varicella between weeks 13 and 20, there is a higher chance of developing fetal varicella syndrome, also known as congenital varicella syndrome.

Between 13 and 20 weeks of gestation, 2% of newborns with maternal varicella and 0.4% of infants born before 13 weeks of gestation develop congenital varicella syndrome. After 20 weeks, it is uncommon.

Limb hypoplasia (shown below) and cicatricial skin scarring in a zigzag pattern, resembling a zoster, are characteristics of congenital varicella syndrome. Along with ocular characteristics including chorioretinitis, microphthalmia, cataracts, and abnormalities of the renal and autonomic systems like hydronephrosis and neurogenic bladder, they can also exhibit cerebral abnormalities like microcephaly, cortical atrophy, and mental retardation. Moreover, low birth weight is typical.

babies born to women who contracted varicella five days or more before giving birth
